events.title: The Mystery of the Stolen Golden Apples and the Youngest Son's Vigil
detailed_summary: A king owned a garden with a tree that produced golden apples, which were counted regularly.
It was discovered that one apple went missing each night as they ripened.
The angered king ordered the gardener to have someone watch the tree all night.
The gardener's eldest son was assigned to watch first, but he fell asleep around midnight, and another apple disappeared.
The second son was then tasked with watching, but he too fell asleep at midnight, resulting in another missing apple.
The gardener's third son offered to watch. Despite initial reluctance from his father due to fear of harm, he was eventually allowed.
As midnight struck, the youngest son heard a rustling and saw a bird of pure gold flying towards the tree.
While the bird was about to take an apple, the son shot an arrow at it.
The arrow did not injure the bird, but it caused a golden feather to fall from its tail as it flew away.
The next morning, the golden feather was presented to the king and his council.
Everyone agreed the feather's value surpassed the kingdom's entire wealth.
However, the king declared that a single feather was insufficient and he must possess the entire bird.

events.text_segment: A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples. These apples were always counted, and about the time when they began to grow ripe it was found that every night one of them was gone. The king became very angry at this, and ordered the gardener to keep watch all night under the tree. The gardener set his eldest son to watch; but about twelve o’clock he fell asleep, and in the morning another of the apples was missing. Then the second son was ordered to watch; and at midnight he too fell asleep, and in the morning another apple was gone. Then the third son offered to keep watch; but the gardener at first would not let him, for fear some harm should come to him: however, at last he consented, and the young man laid himself under the tree to watch. As the clock struck twelve he heard a rustling noise in the air, and a bird came flying that was of pure gold; and as it was snapping at one of the apples with its beak, the gardener’s son jumped up and shot an arrow at it. But the arrow did the bird no harm; only it dropped a golden feather from its tail, and then flew away. The golden feather was brought to the king in the morning, and all the council was called together. Everyone agreed that it was worth more than all the wealth of the kingdom: but the king said, ‘One feather is of no use to me, I must have the whole bird.’

A certain king had a beautiful garden, and in the garden stood a tree which bore golden apples. These apples were the pride of the kingdom, shimmering like the sun itself, and their sweet fragrance filled the air. The king guarded the tree jealously, for it was said that whoever ate one of its golden apples would be granted great wisdom and eternal youth.  

But one morning, the king awoke to find that one of the apples had gone missing. Furious, he ordered his guards to watch the tree night and day. Yet, no matter how carefully they kept watch, another apple vanished the next night, and then another. The king grew desperate, for the tree’s magic was fading with each stolen fruit.  

At last, the king’s youngest son, a brave and clever prince, offered to uncover the thief. That night, he hid beneath the tree, his cloak pulled tight against the cold. As the moon rose high, he heard a soft rustling in the branches. Looking up, he saw not a man, but a magnificent golden bird, its feathers gleaming as it plucked an apple with its beak.  

The prince leapt up, but the bird was swift—it darted away, dropping a single feather in its flight. The prince picked it up, marveling at its radiance. "This is no ordinary thief," he whispered. Determined to solve the mystery, he set off at dawn, following the trail of golden feathers that led deep into the enchanted forest.  

Little did he know, his quest would lead him to wonders and dangers beyond his wildest dreams.

events.title: The Elder Sons' Disregard for Counsel and Subsequent Failures
detailed_summary: The gardener's eldest son embarked on a quest for the golden bird, expecting an easy search.
Early in his journey, he encountered a fox near a wood and prepared to shoot it.
The fox implored him not to shoot, offering valuable advice regarding his quest for the golden bird.
The fox forewarned him about a village with two opposing inns he would reach by evening, advising him to choose the poorer-looking one over the pleasant, beautiful one.
The son internally dismissed the fox's advice, doubting a mere animal's wisdom, and shot at the fox but missed as it escaped into the wood.
Upon reaching the village, he found one inn lively with singing, dancing, and feasting, while the other appeared dirty and impoverished.
Believing it foolish to choose the shabby inn over the charming one, he entered the luxurious establishment, indulged himself, and forgot about the golden bird and his homeland.
After a significant time passed with no news from the eldest son, the second son set out on the same quest.
He encountered the same fox, who provided the identical counsel about the inns.
However, upon arriving at the village, the second son saw his eldest brother at the window of the merry inn, beckoning him inside.
Unable to resist the allure, he entered, and similarly forgot his quest for the golden bird and his country.

events.text_segment:
Then the gardener’s eldest son set out and thought to find the golden bird very easily; and when he had gone but a little way, he came to a wood, and by the side of the wood he saw a fox sitting; so he took his bow and made ready to shoot at it. Then the fox said, ‘Do not shoot me, for I will give you good counsel; I know what your business is, and that you want to find the golden bird. You will reach a village in the evening; and when you get there, you will see two inns opposite to each other, one of which is very pleasant and beautiful to look at: go not in there, but rest for the night in the other, though it may appear to you to be very poor and mean.’ But the son thought to himself, ‘What can such a beast as this know about the matter?’ So he shot his arrow at the fox; but he missed it, and it set up its tail above its back and ran into the wood. Then he went his way, and in the evening came to the village where the two inns were; and in one of these were people singing, and dancing, and feasting; but the other looked very dirty, and poor. ‘I should be very silly,’ said he, ‘if I went to that shabby house, and left this charming place’; so he went into the smart house, and ate and drank at his ease, and forgot the bird, and his country too.
Time passed on; and as the eldest son did not come back, and no tidings were heard of him, the second son set out, and the same thing happened to him. He met the fox, who gave him the good advice: but when he came to the two inns, his eldest brother was standing at the window where the merrymaking was, and called to him to come in; and he could not withstand the temptation, but went in, and forgot the golden bird and his country in the same manner.

events.text_segment:
Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right—all that falls to them is so much gain—all their geese are swans—all their cards are trumps—toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster. The world may very likely not always think of them as they think of themselves, but what care they for the world? what can it know about the matter?
One of these lucky beings was neighbour Hans. Seven long years he had worked hard for his master. At last he said, ‘Master, my time is up; I must go home and see my poor mother once more: so pray pay me my wages and let me go.’ And the master said, ‘You have been a faithful and good servant, Hans, so your pay shall be handsome.’ Then he gave him a lump of silver as big as his head.
Hans took out his pocket-handkerchief, put the piece of silver into it, threw it over his shoulder, and jogged off on his road homewards. As he went lazily on, dragging one foot after another, a man came in sight, trotting gaily along on a capital horse. ‘Ah!’ said Hans aloud, ‘what a fine thing it is to ride on horseback! There he sits as easy and happy as if he was at home, in the chair by his fireside; he trips against no stones, saves shoe-leather, and gets on he hardly knows how.’ Hans did not speak so softly but the horseman heard it all, and said, ‘Well, friend, why do you go on foot then?’ ‘Ah!’ said he, ‘I have this load to carry: to be sure it is silver, but it is so heavy that I can’t hold up my head, and you must know it hurts my shoulder sadly.’ ‘What do you say of making an exchange?’ said the horseman. ‘I will give you my horse, and you shall give me the silver; which will save you a great deal of trouble in carrying such a heavy load about with you.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said Hans: ‘but as you are so kind to me, I must tell you one thing—you will have a weary task to draw that silver about with you.’ However, the horseman got off, took the silver, helped Hans up, gave him the bridle into one hand and the whip into the other, and said, ‘When you want to go very fast, smack your lips loudly together, and cry “Jip!”’

At last he said, 'Master, my time is up; I must go home and see my poor mother once more: so pray pay me my wages and let me go.' And the master said, 'You have been a faithful and good servant, Hans, so your pay shall be handsome.' Then he gave him a lump of silver as big as his head.  

Hans took out his pocket-handkerchief, put the piece of silver into it, threw it over his shoulder, and jogged off on his road homewards. As he went lazily on, dragging one foot after another, a man came in sight, trotting gaily along on a capital horse. 'Ah!' said Hans aloud, 'what a fine thing it is to ride on horseback! There he sits as easy and happy as if he was at home, in the chair by his fireside; he trips against no stones, saves shoe-leather, and gets on he hardly knows how.'  

The horseman heard this, and said, 'Well, friend, why do you go on foot then?' 'Ah!' said he, 'I have this load to carry: to be sure it is silver, but it is so heavy that I can't hold up my head, and you must know it hurts my shoulder sadly.' 'What do you say of making an exchange?' said the horseman. 'I will give you my horse, and you shall give me the silver; which will save you a great deal of trouble in carrying such a heavy load about with you.'  

'With all my heart,' said Hans: 'but as you are so kind to me, I must tell you one thing—you will have a weary task to drag that silver about with you.' However, the horseman got off, took the silver, helped Hans up, gave him the bridle into one hand and the whip into the other, and said, 'When you want to go very fast, smack your lips loudly together, and cry "Jip!"'  

---

events.title: A Brief Ride, a Fall, and a Trade: Horse for Cow
detailed_summary: Initially, Hans was thrilled with his new horse, riding along joyfully, whistling and singing a song about being carefree.
He decided to increase his speed and, using the command "Jip!", caused the horse to bolt into a full gallop.
Before Hans could react, he was thrown from the horse and landed on his back by the roadside.
A shepherd, who was passing by driving a cow, managed to stop Hans's horse before it could run off completely.
Hans, having recovered but feeling quite annoyed, complained to the shepherd about the treacherous nature of riding such a spirited animal, noting how it had damaged his coat in a puddle.
He then expressed a strong preference for the shepherd's cow, imagining the ease of walking behind it and the daily benefits of milk, butter, and cheese.
The shepherd, stating a desire to help his neighbors even at a personal loss, offered to trade his cow for Hans's horse.
Hans cheerfully agreed to the swap, privately marveling at what he perceived as the shepherd's noble and generous heart.
The shepherd then mounted the horse, bid Hans farewell, and rode away.

Hans was delighted as he sat on the horse, drew himself up, squared his elbows, turned out his toes, cracked his whip, and rode merrily off, one minute whistling a merry tune, and another singing,
"No care and no sorrow,
A fig for the morrow!
We’ll laugh and be merry,
Sing neigh down derry!"
After a time he thought he should like to go a little faster, so he smacked his lips and cried ‘Jip!’ Away went the horse full gallop; and before Hans knew what he was about, he was thrown off, and lay on his back by the road-side. His horse would have ran off, if a shepherd who was coming by, driving a cow, had not stopped it. Hans soon came to himself, and got upon his legs again, sadly vexed, and said to the shepherd, ‘This riding is no joke, when a man has the luck to get upon a beast like this that stumbles and flings him off as if it would break his neck. However, I’m off now once for all: I like your cow now a great deal better than this smart beast that played me this trick, and has spoiled my best coat, you see, in this puddle; which, by the by, smells not very like a nosegay. One can walk along at one’s leisure behind that cow—keep good company, and have milk, butter, and cheese, every day, into the bargain. What would I give to have such a prize!’ ‘Well,’ said the shepherd, ‘if you are so fond of her, I will change my cow for your horse; I like to do good to my neighbours, even though I lose by it myself.’ ‘Done!’ said Hans, merrily. ‘What a noble heart that good man has!’ thought he. Then the shepherd jumped upon the horse, wished Hans and the cow good morning, and away he rode.

events.title: The Unproductive Cow and Trading for a Pig
detailed_summary: After tidying himself up, Hans drove his new cow along, feeling very fortunate about his latest bargain.
He daydreamed about enjoying bread with his own butter and cheese, and drinking fresh milk whenever he was thirsty, considering these things the epitome of contentment.
Upon reaching an inn, he stopped, ate all the bread he had, and spent his very last penny on a glass of beer.
Continuing his journey towards his mother's village, he found himself on a vast, hot heath as noon approached, becoming extremely thirsty.
Confident he could remedy his thirst, Hans attempted to milk the cow, tying her to a tree and using his cap as a pail, only to discover she yielded no milk at all.
During his clumsy and unsuccessful milking efforts, the cow grew agitated and delivered a kick to Hans's head, rendering him unconscious for a significant time.
Fortunately, a butcher driving a pig in a wheelbarrow came by and helped Hans to his feet.
Hans recounted his unfortunate experience with the dry cow.
The butcher offered Hans a flask of ale and explained that the cow was old and only fit for slaughter, not for providing milk.
Hans lamented this turn of events, expressing regret over trading his horse for a useless cow and wishing he had a pig instead, which could at least be used for sausages.
The butcher, framing it as a kind and neighborly gesture, offered to exchange his pig for Hans's cow.
Hans accepted with gratitude, gave the cow to the butcher, took the pig, and continued his journey, feeling that his previous misfortunes were now fully rectified by this new acquisition.

events.text_segment:
Hans brushed his coat, wiped his face and hands, rested a while, and then drove off his cow quietly, and thought his bargain a very lucky one. ‘If I have only a piece of bread (and I certainly shall always be able to get that), I can, whenever I like, eat my butter and cheese with it; and when I am thirsty I can milk my cow and drink the milk: and what can I wish for more?’ When he came to an inn, he halted, ate up all his bread, and gave away his last penny for a glass of beer. When he had rested himself he set off again, driving his cow towards his mother’s village. But the heat grew greater as soon as noon came on, till at last, as he found himself on a wide heath that would take him more than an hour to cross, he began to be so hot and parched that his tongue clave to the roof of his mouth. ‘I can find a cure for this,’ thought he; ‘now I will milk my cow and quench my thirst’: so he tied her to the stump of a tree, and held his leathern cap to milk into; but not a drop was to be had. Who would have thought that this cow, which was to bring him milk and butter and cheese, was all that time utterly dry? Hans had not thought of looking to that.
While he was trying his luck in milking, and managing the matter very clumsily, the uneasy beast began to think him very troublesome; and at last gave him such a kick on the head as knocked him down; and there he lay a long while senseless. Luckily a butcher soon came by, driving a pig in a wheelbarrow. ‘What is the matter with you, my man?’ said the butcher, as he helped him up. Hans told him what had happened, how he was dry, and wanted to milk his cow, but found the cow was dry too. Then the butcher gave him a flask of ale, saying, ‘There, drink and refresh yourself; your cow will give you no milk: don’t you see she is an old beast, good for nothing but the slaughter-house?’ ‘Alas, alas!’ said Hans, ‘who would have thought it? The next man he met was a countryman carrying a fine white goose. The countryman stopped to ask what was o’clock; this led to further chat; and Hans told him all his luck, how he had so many good bargains, and how all the world went gay and smiling with him. The countryman then began to tell his tale, and said he was going to take the goose to a christening. ‘Feel,’ said he, ‘how heavy it is, and yet it is only eight weeks old. Whoever roasts and eats it will find plenty of fat upon it, it has lived so well!’ ‘You’re right,’ said Hans, as he weighed it in his hand; ‘but if you talk of fat, my pig is no trifle.’ Meantime the countryman began to look grave, and shook his head. ‘Hark ye!’ said he, ‘my worthy friend, you seem a good sort of fellow, so I can’t help doing you a kind turn. Your pig may get you into a scrape. In the village I just came from, the squire has had a pig stolen out of his sty. I was dreadfully afraid when I saw you that you had got the squire’s pig. If you have, and they catch you, it will be a bad job for you. The least they will do will be to throw you into the horse-pond. Can you swim?’
Poor Hans was sadly frightened. ‘Good man,’ cried he, ‘pray get me out of this scrape. I know nothing of where the pig was either bred or born; but he may have been the squire’s for aught I can tell: you know this country better than I do, take my pig and give me the goose.’ ‘I ought to have something into the bargain,’ said the countryman; ‘give a fat goose for a pig, indeed! ‘Tis not everyone would do so much for you as that. However, I will not be hard upon you, as you are in trouble.’ Then he took the string in his hand, and drove off the pig by a side path; while Hans went on the way homewards free from care. ‘After all,’ thought he, ‘that chap is pretty well taken in. I don’t care whose pig it is, but wherever it came from it has been a very good friend to me. I have much the best of the bargain. First there will be a capital roast; then the fat will find me in goose-grease for six months; and then there are all the beautiful white feathers. I will put them into my pillow, and then I am sure I shall sleep soundly without rocking. How happy my mother will be! Talk of a pig, indeed! Give me a fine fat goose.’

"O’er hill and o’er dale

Hans stood looking on for a while, and at last said, ‘You must be well off, master grinder! you seem so happy at your work.’ ‘Yes,’ said the other, ‘mine is a golden trade; a good grinder never puts his hand into his pocket without finding money in it—but where did you get that beautiful goose?’ ‘I did not buy it, I gave a pig for it.’ ‘And where did you get the pig?’ ‘I gave a cow for it.’ ‘And the cow?’ ‘I gave a horse for it.’ ‘And the horse?’ ‘I gave a lump of silver as big as my head for it.’ ‘And the silver?’ ‘Oh! Why, you must turn grinder like myself,’ said the other; ‘you only want a grindstone; the rest will come of itself. Here is one that is but little the worse for wear: I would not ask more than the value of your goose for it—will you buy?’ ‘How can you ask?’ said Hans; ‘I should be the happiest man in the world, if I could have money whenever I put my hand in my pocket: what could I want more? there’s the goose.’ ‘Now,’ said the grinder, as he gave him a common rough stone that lay by his side, ‘this is a most capital stone; do but work it well enough, and you can make an old nail cut with it.’

events.title: The Grindstone's Burden, Accidental Loss, and Joyful Arrival
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, Hans began to feel the effects of his journey and his earlier generosity; he was tired and hungry, having spent his last penny after acquiring the cow.
The grindstone proved to be a heavy burden, eventually exhausting him to the point where he could go no further.
He managed to drag himself to the bank of a river to drink water and rest, carefully placing the stone beside him.
However, as he bent down to drink, he inadvertently nudged the stone, causing it to roll down the bank and plunge into the stream.
Hans watched the stone sink into the clear water for a moment.

Then, instead of being dismayed, he suddenly sprang up, danced with joy, and fell to his knees, tearfully thanking Heaven for its kindness in removing what he now perceived as his only burden, the "ugly heavy stone."
Exclaiming how happy and uniquely lucky he was, Hans rose with a light heart, feeling entirely free from all his troubles.
He then continued his journey until he finally reached his mother's house, where he shared with her his story of how easily he had found the path to good luck.

events.title: The Enchanted Castle and the Fairy's Curse
detailed_summary: An ancient castle in a dark forest was home to an old fairy with shapeshifting abilities.
By day, she would transform into an owl or a cat, but at night, she reverted to her form as an old woman.
Any young man who ventured within a hundred paces of her castle would be magically frozen in place until she released him, on the condition he never returned.
However, any pretty maiden who came within that same distance was turned into a bird, caged, and hung in a chamber within the castle.
The castle contained seven hundred such cages, each holding a beautiful bird.

events.title: Jorinda and Jorindel's Fateful Walk and Growing Unease
detailed_summary: A maiden named Jorinda, renowned for her exceptional beauty, was betrothed to a shepherd lad named Jorindel who loved her dearly.
One day, they sought solitude by walking together in the woods.
Jorindel voiced a caution, reminding Jorinda that they needed to be careful not to stray too close to the fairy's castle.
The evening was idyllic, with the sun's fading rays illuminating the forest floor and turtle-doves cooing from the birch trees.
As Jorinda and Jorindel sat together, an inexplicable sadness overcame them, accompanied by a strong premonition that they were about to be separated forever.
They realized they had wandered a significant distance and were now lost, unsure of the way back home.

He informed his companions, suggesting a house was nearby.
The ass thought it wise to investigate this potentially better lodging.
The dog concurred, mentioning its desire for a bone or some meat.
The group then proceeded towards the light Chanticleer had seen, which grew larger and brighter as they neared, eventually leading them to a house occupied by robbers.

events.title: The Wolf's Deceptive Rescue Plan and Its Successful Execution
detailed_summary: The wolf comforted Sultan and outlined a clever strategy to save him.
According to the plan, when the shepherd and his wife were in the field with their child, the wolf would emerge from the woods and pretend to abduct the child.
Sultan was instructed to lie near the child as if guarding it, then vigorously chase the wolf, who would then drop the child.
Sultan would then retrieve the child, appearing as its savior to his master and mistress.
The plan was executed perfectly; the wolf ran off with the child, the parents screamed, Sultan pursued and brought the child back.
Overjoyed and grateful, the shepherd declared that Sultan had saved their child and would be cared for, well-fed, and even given the shepherd's old cushion to sleep on for the rest of his life.
From that point on, Sultan enjoyed a life of comfort and abundance.

Your master, you know, goes out every morning very early with his wife into the field; and they take their little child with them, and lay it down behind the hedge in the shade while they are at work. Now do you lie down close by the child, and pretend to be watching it, and I will come out of the wood and run away with it; you must run after me as fast as you can, and I will let it drop; then you may carry it back, and they will think you have saved their child, and will be so thankful to you that they will take care of you as long as you live.’ The dog liked this plan very well; and accordingly so it was managed. The wolf ran with the child a little way; the shepherd and his wife screamed out; but Sultan soon overtook him, and carried the poor little thing back to his master and mistress. Then the shepherd patted him on the head, and said, ‘Old Sultan has saved our child from the wolf, and therefore he shall live and be well taken care of, and have plenty to eat. Wife, go home, and give him a good dinner, and let him have my old cushion to sleep on as long as he lives.’ So from this time forward Sultan had all that he could wish for.

events.title: An Unlikely Encounter and Shared Escapes
detailed_summary: An impoverished elderly woman gathered beans for cooking.
She started a fire on her hearth using straw for kindling.
While transferring beans to a pan, one bean fell unnoticed to the ground, landing near a piece of straw.
A burning coal then leaped from the fire, joining the bean and straw.
The straw initiated a conversation, inquiring about the origins of the bean and coal.
The coal recounted its fortunate escape from the fire, which would have otherwise reduced it to ashes.
The bean shared its own narrow escape, explaining that it would have been boiled into broth with its companions if the old woman had put it in the pan.
The straw lamented the fate of its fellow straws, all destroyed by fire and smoke by the old woman, and expressed relief at its own accidental escape.

events.title: The Enchanted Slumber Descends Upon the Palace
detailed_summary: The princess had not died, but rather had succumbed to a very deep sleep.
The king and queen, who had just arrived back at the palace, along with their entire retinue, also fell into a slumber.
This magical sleep permeated the entire palace grounds: horses dozed in their stalls, dogs slept in the courtyard, pigeons rested on the rooftop, and even flies remained motionless on the walls.

The enchantment extended to inanimate objects as well: the fire in the hearth ceased its burning and appeared to sleep; the mechanism turning the roasting spit stopped, and the spit itself, holding a goose for the king's meal, became still.
The cook, in the midst of pulling a kitchen-boy's hair to reprimand him, was frozen in the act, and both she and the boy fell asleep.
The butler, who was surreptitiously tasting the ale, also fell asleep with the drinking vessel poised at his lips.
In this manner, every person and object within the palace came to a halt and entered a state of profound sleep.

events.title: The Awakening Kiss and the Revival of the Palace
detailed_summary: The prince ventured further into the palace, where the silence was so profound he could hear his own respirations.
At last, he reached the old tower and unlatched the door of the small chamber where Briar Rose was located.
There she lay, deeply asleep on a couch near the window, her beauty so captivating he could not avert his gaze.
Overcome by her appearance, he bent down and bestowed a kiss upon her.
The very moment his lips touched hers, Briar Rose's eyes fluttered open, she awoke, and offered him a smile.
Together, they exited the room.
Concurrently, the king and queen also awoke, as did the entire court, all of them looking at one another with immense surprise.
The horses began to move and shake their bodies, the dogs leaped up and barked, and the pigeons lifted their heads from under their wings, surveyed their surroundings, and flew out into the fields.
The flies on the walls resumed their buzzing.

events.title: Retribution at Home: The Sparrow and a Swarm Devour the Carter's Corn
detailed_summary: Compelled to abandon his cart, the carter returned home, overwhelmed with rage and vexation.
He recounted his misfortunes to his wife, detailing the spilled wine and the death of all three horses.
His wife, in turn, informed him that a malevolent bird had entered their house, bringing with it what seemed like every bird in existence.
She reported that this avian horde was in their loft, rapidly devouring their stored corn.
The husband rushed upstairs and witnessed thousands of birds on the floor consuming his grain, with the familiar sparrow in their midst.
Seeing that almost all his corn was gone, the carter cried out in despair about his wretched state.
The sparrow retorted that he was still not wretched enough and forewarned that his cruelty would ultimately cost him his life, before flying away.

events.title: The Sparrow's Final Taunt and the Carter's Fatal Rage
detailed_summary: The carter, having witnessed the loss of all his possessions, descended to his kitchen, still showing no remorse for his actions, and sat angrily in the chimney corner.
The sparrow positioned itself outside the window and cried out that the carter's cruelty would cost him his life.
In a fit of rage, the carter sprang up, seized his hatchet, and hurled it at the sparrow.
The hatchet missed the bird but shattered the windowpane.
The sparrow then hopped inside, perched upon the window-seat, and repeated its dire warning about the cost of the carter's life.
Driven mad and blind with fury, the carter struck the window-seat with such force that he split it in two.

As the sparrow darted from place to place within the room, the carter and his wife, in their furious attempts to strike it, ended up breaking all their furniture, glassware, and even damaging the walls, without managing to touch the bird.
Ultimately, however, they succeeded in capturing the sparrow.
The wife inquired if she should kill it immediately.
The carter, desiring a more agonizing end for the bird, declared that merely killing it was too lenient and that he would eat it instead.
The sparrow began to flutter and stretch its neck, crying out one final time that the carter's cruelty would yet cost him his life.
Unable to delay any longer, the carter handed his wife the hatchet and commanded her to strike the bird and kill it while he held it in his hand.
The wife swung the hatchet, but her aim was errant; she missed the sparrow and instead struck her husband on the head.
The carter fell down dead, and the sparrow flew serenely back to its nest.

"Pride will not fill your belly," she murmured, but he did not listen.

He promised that any man who could reveal where the princesses danced would win the hand of his chosen daughter in marriage and be designated as the successor to the throne.
However, the proclamation carried a dire warning: any contender who failed to solve the mystery within three days and nights would face execution.

There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters. They slept in twelve beds all in one room, and when they went to bed, the doors were shut and locked up. But every morning their shoes were found to be quite worn through as if they had been danced in all night. Nobody could find out how it happened, or where the princesses had been.  

So the king made it known to all the land that if any person could discover the secret and find out where it was that the princesses danced in the night, he should have the one he liked best for his wife and should be king after his death. But whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.  

A king’s son soon came. He was well entertained, and in the evening was taken to the chamber next to the one where the princesses lay in their twelve beds. There he was to sit and watch where they went to dance; and, that they might do nothing without his knowing it, the door of his chamber was left open. But the king’s son soon fell asleep, and when he awoke in the morning, he found that the princesses had all been dancing, for the soles of their shoes were full of holes. The same thing happened the second and third nights, so the king ordered his head to be cut off.  

After him came several others, but they all had the same luck, and all lost their lives in the same way.  

Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where this king reigned. He met an old woman, who asked him where he was going.  

"I hardly know where I am going, or what I had better do," said the soldier. "But I think I should like very well to find out where it is that the princesses dance, and then in time I might be a king."  

"Well," said the old woman, "that is not a very hard task. Only you must not drink the wine which one of the princesses will bring to you in the evening, and you must pretend to be fast asleep."  

Then she gave him a little cloak and said, "As soon as you put that on, you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go."  

When the soldier heard all this good advice, he determined to try his luck. So he went to the king and said he was willing to undertake the task.  

He was as well received as the others had been, and the king ordered fine royal robes to be given him. When the evening came, he was led to the outer chamber.  

Now, as soon as he was left alone, one of the princesses brought him a cup of wine. But the soldier had tied a sponge under his chin and let the wine run down into it, so that he did not drink a drop. Then he lay down, and in a little while began to snore very loudly, as if he were fast asleep.  

When the twelve princesses heard this, they laughed heartily, and the eldest said, "This fellow, too, might have done a wiser thing than lose his life in this way!"  

Then they rose and opened their drawers and boxes, took out all their fine clothes, dressed themselves at the glass, and skipped about as if they were eager to begin dancing. But the youngest said, "I don’t know how it is, but while you are so happy, I feel very uneasy. I am sure some misfortune is about to befall us."  

"You simpleton," said the eldest, "you are always afraid. Have you forgotten how many kings’ sons have already watched in vain? As for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough."  

When they were all ready, they looked carefully about, but they did not think of the invisible soldier who was watching them. Then the eldest went up to her own bed and clapped her hands, and the bed sank into the floor, and a trapdoor flew open. The soldier saw them going down through the trapdoor one after another, the eldest leading the way.  

He thought it would not be wise for him to delay, so he sprang up, put on the little cloak the old woman had given him, and followed them. But in going down the stairs, he accidentally stepped on the gown of the youngest princess, and she cried out to her sisters, "All is not right! Someone took hold of my gown!"  

"You silly creature!" said the eldest. "It is nothing but a nail in the wall."  

So they went down till they came to a grove of trees where the leaves were all of silver, and they shone brightly. The soldier broke off a twig, and there came a loud crack.  

The youngest princess jumped again and said, "I am sure all is not right! Did not you hear that noise? That never happened before."  

But the eldest said, "It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach."  

Then they came to another grove of trees where all the leaves were of gold, and afterward to a third where the leaves were of glittering diamonds. The soldier broke a twig from each, and every time there was a loud crack, which made the youngest princess start with terror. But the eldest still insisted it was only the princes shouting for joy.  

So they went on till they came to a great lake, and at the side of the lake there lay twelve little boats with twelve handsome princes in them, who seemed to be waiting there for the princesses.  

One of the princesses went into each boat, and the soldier stepped into the same boat with the youngest. As they were rowing over the lake, the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess said, "I do not know why it is, but though I am rowing with all my might, we do not get on so fast as usual, and I am quite tired. The boat seems very heavy today."  

"It is only the heat of the weather," said the princess. "I feel it very warm too."  

On the other side of the lake stood a fine, illuminated castle, from which came the merry music of horns and trumpets. There they all landed and went into the castle, and each prince danced with his princess, and the soldier, who was still invisible, danced with them too.  

When any of the princesses had a cup of wine set by her, he drank it all up, so that when she put the cup to her mouth it was empty. At this, too, the youngest princess was terribly frightened, but the eldest always silenced her.  

They danced on till three o’clock in the morning, and then all their shoes were worn out, so that they were obliged to leave off. The princes rowed them back again over the lake, but this time the soldier placed himself in the boat with the eldest princess.  

On the opposite shore they took leave of each other, the princesses promising to come again the next night.  

When they came to the stairs, the soldier ran on before the princesses and laid himself down, and as the twelve sisters came up very slowly, they heard him snoring in his bed.  

"There!" said they. "Now we are quite safe." So they undressed themselves, put away their fine clothes, pulled off their shoes, and went to bed.  

In the morning the soldier said nothing about what had happened, but determined to see more of this strange adventure, and went again the second and third nights. Everything happened just as before. The princesses danced each time till their shoes were worn to pieces, and then returned home.  

On the third night the soldier carried away one of the golden cups as a token of where he had been.  

As soon as the time came when he was to declare the secret, he was taken before the king with the three branches and the golden cup.  

The twelve princesses stood listening behind the door to hear what he would say.  

And when the king asked him, "Where do my twelve daughters dance at night?" he answered, "With twelve princes in a castle underground."  

And then he told the king all that had happened and showed him the three branches and the golden cup which he had brought with him.

There was a king who had twelve beautiful daughters. They slept in twelve beds all in one room, and when they went to bed, the doors were shut and locked up. But every morning their shoes were found to be quite worn through as if they had been danced in all night. Nobody could find out how it happened, or where the princesses had been.  

So the king made it known to all the land that if any person could discover the secret and find out where it was that the princesses danced in the night, he should have the one he liked best for his wife and should be king after his death. But whoever tried and did not succeed, after three days and nights, should be put to death.  

A king’s son soon came. He was well entertained, and in the evening was taken to the chamber next to the one where the princesses lay in their twelve beds. There he was to sit and watch where they went to dance; and, that they might do nothing without his knowing it, the door of his chamber was left open. But the king’s son soon fell asleep, and when he awoke in the morning, he found that the princesses had all been dancing, for the soles of their shoes were full of holes. The same thing happened the second and third nights, so the king ordered his head to be cut off.  

After him came several others, but they all had the same luck, and all lost their lives in the same way.  

Now it chanced that an old soldier, who had been wounded in battle and could fight no longer, passed through the country where this king reigned. He met an old woman, who asked him where he was going.  

"I hardly know where I am going, or what I had better do," said the soldier. "But I think I should like very well to find out where it is that the princesses dance, and then in time I might be a king."  

"Well," said the old woman, "that is not a very hard task. Only you must not drink the wine which one of the princesses will bring to you in the evening, and you must pretend to be fast asleep."  

Then she gave him a little cloak and said, "As soon as you put that on, you will become invisible, and you will then be able to follow the princesses wherever they go."  

When the soldier heard all this good advice, he determined to try his luck. So he went to the king and said he was willing to undertake the task.  

He was as well received as the others had been, and the king ordered fine royal robes to be given him. When the evening came, he was led to the outer chamber.  

Now, as soon as he was left alone, one of the princesses brought him a cup of wine. But the soldier had tied a sponge under his chin and let the wine run down into it, so that he did not drink a drop. Then he lay down, and in a little while began to snore very loudly, as if he were fast asleep.  

When the twelve princesses heard this, they laughed heartily, and the eldest said, "This fellow, too, might have done a wiser thing than lose his life in this way!"  

Then they rose and opened their drawers and boxes, took out all their fine clothes, dressed themselves at the glass, and skipped about as if they were eager to begin dancing. But the youngest said, "I don’t know how it is, but while you are so happy, I feel very uneasy. I am sure some misfortune is about to befall us."  

"You simpleton," said the eldest, "you are always afraid. Have you forgotten how many kings’ sons have already watched in vain? As for this soldier, even if I had not given him his sleeping draught, he would have slept soundly enough."  

When they were all ready, they looked carefully about, but they did not think of the invisible soldier who was watching them. Then the eldest went up to her own bed and clapped her hands, and the bed sank into the floor, and a trapdoor flew open. The soldier saw them going down through the trapdoor one after another, the eldest leading the way.  

He thought it would not be wise for him to delay, so he sprang up, put on the little cloak the old woman had given him, and followed them. But in going down the stairs, he accidentally stepped on the gown of the youngest princess, and she cried out to her sisters, "All is not right! Someone took hold of my gown!"  

"You silly creature!" said the eldest. "It is nothing but a nail in the wall."  

So they went down till they came to a grove of trees where the leaves were all of silver, and they shone brightly. The soldier broke off a twig, and there came a loud crack.  

The youngest princess jumped again and said, "I am sure all is not right! Did not you hear that noise? That never happened before."  

But the eldest said, "It is only our princes, who are shouting for joy at our approach."  

Then they came to another grove of trees where all the leaves were of gold, and afterward to a third where the leaves were of glittering diamonds. The soldier broke a twig from each, and every time there was a loud crack, which made the youngest princess start with terror. But the eldest still insisted it was only the princes shouting for joy.  

So they went on till they came to a great lake, and at the side of the lake there lay twelve little boats with twelve handsome princes in them, who seemed to be waiting there for the princesses.  

One of the princesses went into each boat, and the soldier stepped into the same boat with the youngest. As they were rowing over the lake, the prince who was in the boat with the youngest princess said, "I do not know why it is, but though I am rowing with all my might, we do not get on so fast as usual, and I am quite tired. The boat seems very heavy today."  

"It is only the heat of the weather," said the princess. "I feel it very warm too."  

On the other side of the lake stood a fine, illuminated castle, from which came the merry music of horns and trumpets. There they all landed and went into the castle, and each prince danced with his princess, and the soldier, who was still invisible, danced with them too.  

When any of the princesses had a cup of wine set by her, he drank it all up, so that when she put the cup to her mouth it was empty. At this, too, the youngest princess was terribly frightened, but the eldest always silenced her.  

They danced on till three o’clock in the morning, and then all their shoes were worn out, so that they were obliged to leave off. The princes rowed them back again over the lake, but this time the soldier placed himself in the boat with the eldest princess.  

On the opposite shore they took leave of each other, the princesses promising to come again the next night.  

When they came to the stairs, the soldier ran on before the princesses and laid himself down, and as the twelve sisters came up very slowly, they heard him snoring in his bed.  

"There!" said they. "Now we are quite safe." So they undressed themselves, put away their fine clothes, pulled off their shoes, and went to bed.  

In the morning the soldier said nothing about what had happened, but determined to see more of this strange adventure, and went again the second and third nights. Everything happened just as before. The princesses danced each time till their shoes were worn to pieces, and then returned home.  

On the third night the soldier carried away one of the golden cups as a token of where he had been.  

As soon as the time came when he was to declare the secret, he was taken before the king with the three branches and the golden cup.  

The twelve princesses stood listening behind the door to hear what he would say.  

And when the king asked him, "Where do my twelve daughters dance at night?" he answered, "With twelve princes in a castle underground."  

And then he told the king all that had happened and showed him the three branches and the golden cup which he had brought with him.  

Then the king called for the princesses and asked them whether what the soldier said was true. When they saw that they were discovered and that it was of no use to deny what had happened, they confessed it all.  

And the king asked the soldier which of them he would choose for his wife.  

He answered, "I am not very young, so I will have the eldest."  

And they were married that very day, and the soldier was chosen to be the king’s heir.

events.text_segment:
Everything went right for a week or two, and then Dame Ilsabill said, ‘Husband, there is not near room enough for us in this cottage; the courtyard and the garden are a great deal too small; I should like to have a large stone castle to live in: go to the fish again and tell him to give us a castle.’ ‘Wife,’ said the fisherman, ‘I don’t like to go to him again, for perhaps he will be angry; we ought to be easy with this pretty cottage to live in.’ ‘Nonsense!’ said the wife; ‘he will do it very willingly, I know; go along and try!’
The fisherman went, but his heart was very heavy: and when he came to the sea, it looked blue and gloomy, though it was very calm; and he went close to the edge of the waves, and said:
 ‘O man of the sea!
  Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’
‘Well, what does she want now?’ said the fish. ‘Ah!’ said the man, dolefully, ‘my wife wants to live in a stone castle.’ ‘Go home, then,’ said the fish; ‘she is standing at the gate of it already.’ So away went the fisherman, and found his wife standing before the gate of a great castle. ‘See,’ said she, ‘is not this grand?’ With that they went into the castle together, and found a great many servants there, and the rooms all richly furnished, and full of golden chairs and tables; and behind the castle was a garden, and around it was a park half a mile long, full of sheep, and goats, and hares, and deer; and in the courtyard were stables and cow-houses. ‘Well,’ said the man, ‘now we will live cheerful and happy in this beautiful castle for the rest of our lives.’ ‘Perhaps we may,’ said the wife; ‘but let us sleep upon it, before we make up our minds to that.’ So they went to bed.

The next morning when Dame Ilsabill awoke it was broad daylight, and she jogged the fisherman with her elbow, and said, ‘Get up, husband, and bestir yourself, for we must be king of all the land.’ ‘Wife, wife,’ said the man, ‘why should we wish to be the king?   Hearken to me!
  My wife Ilsabill
  Will have her own will,
  And hath sent me to beg a boon of thee!’

The young wrens react with extreme anger to the insult, vehemently denying the accusations, asserting the honesty of their parents, and warning the bear that he will be made to pay for his words.

One fine evening a young princess put on her bonnet and clogs, and went out to take a walk by herself in a wood; and when she came to a cool spring of water, that rose in the midst of it, she sat herself down to rest a while. Now she had a golden ball in her hand, which was her favourite plaything; and she was always tossing it up into the air, and catching it again as it fell. After a time she threw it up so high that she missed catching it as it fell; and the ball bounded away, and rolled along upon the ground, till at last it fell down into the spring. The princess looked into the spring after her ball, but it was very deep, so deep that she could not see the bottom of it. Then she began to bewail her loss, and said, ‘Alas! if I could only get my ball again, I would give all my fine clothes and jewels, and everything that I have in the world.’
Whilst she was speaking, a frog put its head out of the water, and said, ‘Princess, why do you weep so bitterly?’ ‘Alas!’ said she, ‘what can you do for me, you nasty frog? My golden ball has fallen into the spring.’ The frog said, ‘I want not your pearls, and jewels, and fine clothes; but if you will love me, and let me live with you and eat from off your golden plate, and sleep upon your bed, I will bring you your ball again.’ ‘What nonsense,’ thought the princess, ‘this silly frog is talking! He can never even get out of the spring to visit me, though he may be able to get my ball for me, and therefore I will tell him he shall have what he asks.’ So she said to the frog, ‘Well, if you will bring me my ball, I will do all you ask.’

They follow because they understand my heart. And as for the wind and the trees…’ She smiled faintly. ‘They have been my only companions for a long time.’  

A strange feeling stirred in the king’s chest. ‘Who are you, truly?’  

Before she could answer, a gust of wind swept through the hall, carrying with it a single white feather. The girl caught it, and as she did, her ragged sleeve slipped back, revealing a delicate golden bracelet—one the king recognized at once.  

His voice trembled. ‘That bracelet… it belonged to my lost daughter.’  

The goose-girl’s eyes filled with tears. ‘Father,’ she whispered.  

And so, the true princess was restored, her wicked stepmother’s curse broken at last by the kindness of geese, the whispers of the wind, and a love that even time could not erase.

The old king then solemnly declared, 'Thou art she! And as thou has judged thyself, so shall it be done to thee.'
Following this judgment, the young king was married to his true wife, and they reigned together over the kingdom in peace and happiness for all their lives.
The good fairy later came to visit them and, in a final act of benevolence, restored the faithful Falada to life again.

chapters.chapter_title: THE ADVENTURES OF CHANTICLEER AND PARTLET

events.title: A Journey to the Mountains and a Forced Cart Driver
detailed_summary: Chanticleer suggests to his wife Partlet that they go to the mountains to eat ripe nuts before the squirrel gets them all, and Partlet agrees.
They spend a lovely day in the mountains and stay until evening.
Having eaten so many nuts, or perhaps due to laziness, they decide against walking home.
Chanticleer constructs a small carriage from nutshells.
Partlet gets into the carriage and tells Chanticleer to harness himself and pull her home.
Chanticleer refuses, stating he would rather walk, but offers to be the coachman if Partlet pulls, an offer which is implicitly rejected.
A duck appears, quacking angrily and accusing them of trespassing on her grounds.
The duck attacks Chanticleer.
Chanticleer, being brave, retaliates effectively with his spurs, forcing the duck to beg for mercy.
Mercy is granted on the condition that the duck pulls their carriage home.
The duck agrees, Chanticleer gets on the box as coachman, and they set off at a good speed.

events.text_segment:
‘The nuts are quite ripe now,’ said Chanticleer to his wife Partlet, ‘suppose we go together to the mountains, and eat as many as we can, before the squirrel takes them all away.’ ‘With all my heart,’ said Partlet, ‘let us go and make a holiday of it together.’
So they went to the mountains; and as it was a lovely day, they stayed there till the evening. Now, whether it was that they had eaten so many nuts that they could not walk, or whether they were lazy and would not, I do not know: however, they took it into their heads that it did not become them to go home on foot. So Chanticleer began to build a little carriage of nutshells: and when it was finished, Partlet jumped into it and sat down, and bid Chanticleer harness himself to it and draw her home. ‘That’s a good joke!’ said Chanticleer; ‘no, that will never do; I had rather by half walk home; I’ll sit on the box and be coachman, if you like, but I’ll not draw.’ While this was passing, a duck came quacking up and cried out, ‘You thieving vagabonds, what business have you in my grounds? I’ll give it you well for your insolence!’ and upon that she fell upon Chanticleer most lustily. But Chanticleer was no coward, and returned the duck’s blows with his sharp spurs so fiercely that she soon began to cry out for mercy; which was only granted her upon condition that she would draw the carriage home for them. This she agreed to do; and Chanticleer got upon the box, and drove, crying, ‘Now, duck, get on as fast as you can.’ And away they went at a pretty good pace.

events.title: Acquiring New Passengers and Reaching the Inn
detailed_summary: While travelling, they encounter a needle and a pin walking together.
The needle calls for them to stop, explaining it's very dark, the path is muddy, and they can hardly see.
The needle recounts that he and the pin had been drinking at a public-house and lost track of time.
He requests a ride in their carriage for himself and the pin.
Chanticleer, seeing they are thin and won't take up much space, agrees to give them a lift.
He makes them promise not to dirty the carriage wheels or step on Partlet’s toes.
Late at night, they arrive at an inn.
Deciding it's too difficult to travel in the dark and noting the duck's exhaustion (as it waddled significantly), they decide to stay at the inn.
The landlord is initially reluctant, saying his inn is full, suspecting they might not be respectable guests.

events.title: A New Carriage and a Growing Entourage for Mr. Korbes's Visit
detailed_summary: On another occasion, Chanticleer and Partlet wanted to go for a ride together.
Chanticleer constructed an impressive carriage equipped with four red wheels and harnessed six mice to pull it.
He and Partlet then boarded the carriage and set off.
Shortly after, they encountered a cat, who inquired about their destination.
Chanticleer poetically replied that they were on their way to visit Mr. Korbes, the fox.
The cat asked to accompany them.
Chanticleer agreed willingly, instructing the cat to get up behind and to be careful not to fall off.
He then gave a rhyming command, urging care for his coach and wheels, and readiness from the mice, as they journeyed to Mr. Korbes.
Soon after, a millstone, an egg, a duck, and a pin also approached, and Chanticleer permitted all of them to join the group in the carriage for the visit.

events.title: The Rampion Craving and the Fateful Bargain
detailed_summary: A husband and wife had long wished for a child without success.
Eventually, the wife became pregnant and developed an overwhelming craving for rampion she saw in a neighboring enchantress's garden.
She felt she would die if she couldn't eat it, becoming pale and miserable.
Her alarmed husband, prioritizing her health, decided to get the rampion for her, whatever the cost.
At twilight, he climbed the wall into the enchantress's garden, quickly gathered a handful of rampion, and brought it to his wife.
She immediately prepared a salad from it and ate it with great satisfaction.
The rampion tasted so exceptionally good that the next day her craving became three times stronger.
To find peace, the husband knew he had to venture into the garden again.
As he let himself down into the garden in the evening gloom, he was terrified to find the enchantress standing before him.
The enchantress angrily accused him of thievery and threatened punishment.
The husband pleaded for mercy, explaining his actions were born of necessity as his wife would have died from her longing for the rampion.
The enchantress's anger softened, and she proposed a deal: he could take all the rampion he wished, on the condition that he give her the child his wife would soon bear.
She promised to treat the child well and care for it like a mother.
In his terror, the man agreed to everything.
When the woman gave birth, the enchantress appeared immediately, named the child Rapunzel, and took her away.

events.text_segment: There were once a man and a woman who had long in vain wished for a child. At length the woman hoped that God was about to grant her desire. These people had a little window at the back of their house from which a splendid garden could be seen, which was full of the most beautiful flowers and herbs. It was, however, surrounded by a high wall, and no one dared to go into it because it belonged to an enchantress, who had great power and was dreaded by all the world. One day the woman was standing by this window and looking down into the garden, when she saw a bed which was planted with the most beautiful rampion (rapunzel), and it looked so fresh and green that she longed for it, she quite pined away, and began to look pale and miserable. Then her husband was alarmed, and asked: ‘What ails you, dear wife?’ ‘Ah,’ she replied, ‘if I can’t eat some of the rampion, which is in the garden behind our house, I shall die.’ The man, who loved her, thought: ‘Sooner than let your wife die, bring her some of the rampion yourself, let it cost what it will.’ At twilight, he clambered down over the wall into the garden of the enchantress, hastily clutched a handful of rampion, and took it to his wife. She at once made herself a salad of it, and ate it greedily. It tasted so good to her—so very good, that the next day she longed for it three times as much as before. If he was to have any rest, her husband must once more descend into the garden. In the gloom of evening therefore, he let himself down again; but when he had clambered down the wall he was terribly afraid, for he saw the enchantress standing before him. ‘How can you dare,’ said she with angry look, ‘descend into my garden and steal my rampion like a thief? You shall suffer for it!’ ‘Ah,’ answered he, ‘let mercy take the place of justice, I only made up my mind to do it out of necessity. My wife saw your rampion from the window, and felt such a longing for it that she would have died if she had not got some to eat.’ Then the enchantress allowed her anger to be softened, and said to him: ‘If the case be as you say, I will allow you to take away with you as much rampion as you will, only I make one condition, you must give me the child which your wife will bring into the world; it shall be well treated, and I will care for it like a mother.’ The man in his terror consented to everything, and when the woman was brought to bed, the enchantress appeared at once, gave the child the name of Rapunzel, and took it away with her.

One evening, as the woman sat by the window sewing, she pricked her finger with the needle, and a drop of blood fell upon the snow-white linen. She sighed and said, "Ah, if only I had a child as white as snow, as red as blood, and as black as the wood of the window frame!"  

Not long after, she gave birth to a little girl who was indeed as white as snow, with lips as red as blood, and hair as black as ebony. They named her Snow White, and she was the most beautiful child anyone had ever seen. But the mother, worn from the birth, soon fell ill and passed away, leaving the poor man heartbroken.  

Years passed, and the man, though still grieving, took another wife—a proud and haughty woman who could not bear to be surpassed in beauty. She possessed a magic mirror, and every morning she would stand before it and say:  

*"Mirror, mirror on the wall,*  
*Who is the fairest of them all?"*  

And the mirror would reply:  
*"You, my queen, are fairest of all."*

*"You, my queen, are fair, 'tis true,*

The queen turned pale with rage. From that moment, envy gnawed at her heart like a worm in an apple, and she could not rest until Snow White was gone. She called for a huntsman and commanded him, "Take the child into the forest and kill her. As proof of her death, bring me back her heart."

Exhausted, she lay down and fell asleep, unaware that this was the home of seven dwarfs who worked in the nearby mines.

events.title: Seven at One Stroke: The Tailor's Accidental Feat and Bold Proclamation

Initially, the tailor tries to shoo them away, but the flies, undeterred, return in greater numbers.
Losing his patience, the tailor takes a piece of cloth and strikes the swarm of flies.
Upon counting, he discovers he has killed seven flies with this single blow.
Immensely pleased with his own perceived bravery, he declares that the entire town, and indeed the world, must learn of his feat.
He quickly fashions a girdle and embroiders the words 'Seven at one stroke!' onto it in large letters, his heart swelling with pride.

He inspected each one, lifted it up, put his nose to it, and at length said: ‘The jam seems to me to be good, so weigh me out four ounces, dear woman, and if it is a quarter of a pound that is of no consequence.’ The woman who had hoped to find a good sale, gave him what he desired, but went away quite angry and grumbling. ‘Now, this jam shall be blessed by God,’ cried the little tailor, ‘and give me health and strength’; so he brought the bread out of the cupboard, cut himself a piece right across the loaf and spread the jam over it. ‘This won’t taste bitter,’ said he, ‘but I will just finish the jacket before I take a bite.’ He laid the bread near him, sewed on, and in his joy, made bigger and bigger stitches. In the meantime the smell of the sweet jam rose to where the flies were sitting in great numbers, and they were attracted and descended on it in hosts. ‘Hi! who invited you?’ said the little tailor, and drove the unbidden guests away. The flies, however, who understood no German, would not be turned away, but came back again in ever-increasing companies. The little tailor at last lost all patience, and drew a piece of cloth from the hole under his work-table, and saying: ‘Wait, and I will give it to you,’ struck it mercilessly on them. When he drew it away and counted, there lay before him no fewer than seven, dead and with legs stretched out. ‘Are you a fellow of that sort?’ said he, and could not help admiring his own bravery. ‘The whole town shall know of this!’ And the little tailor hastened to cut himself a girdle, stitched it, and embroidered on it in large letters: ‘Seven at one stroke!’ ‘What, the town!’ he continued, ‘the whole world shall hear of it!’ and his heart wagged with joy like a lamb’s tail.

events.title: The Tailor's Cunning Triumphs Over a Giant's Might
detailed_summary: Wearing his newly embroidered girdle, the tailor decides his workshop is too confining for his newfound valor and resolves to venture into the world.
Before departing, he searches his house for provisions and finds only an old cheese and a bird caught in a thicket, both of which he puts in his pocket.
He travels boldly and without fatigue until he reaches a mountain where a large giant is sitting.
The tailor confidently addresses the giant, proposing they journey together.

The giant initially dismisses the tailor contemptuously, but upon seeing the girdle proclaiming 'Seven at one stroke,' he mistakes this for seven men killed and develops a degree of respect for the small tailor.
Wishing to test him, the giant squeezes a stone until water drips from it and challenges the tailor to do the same.
The tailor nonchalantly pulls out his soft cheese and squeezes it until the whey runs out, claiming it's child's play.
Next, the giant throws a stone so high it's barely visible.
The tailor counters by taking the bird from his pocket and throwing it into the air; the bird flies away, never to return, which the tailor presents as throwing a stone that never comes down.
Impressed, the giant then challenges the tailor to help carry a massive felled oak tree.
The tailor cleverly suggests the giant carry the trunk while he handles the 'heavier' branches and twigs. He then seats himself on a branch, letting the giant unknowingly carry both the tree and him.
When the giant tires and says he must drop the tree, the tailor quickly jumps down and pretends to have been supporting it all along, chiding the giant for his lack of strength.
Continuing together, they reach a cherry tree. The giant bends down a branch laden with ripe fruit for the tailor.
The tailor, too weak to hold the branch, is flung into the air when the giant releases it.
He quickly recovers, claiming he intentionally leaped over the tree because huntsmen were shooting nearby, thereby maintaining his facade of strength and agility before the perplexed giant.

The tailor put on the girdle, and resolved to go forth into the world, because he thought his workshop was too small for his valour. Before he went away, he sought about in the house to see if there was anything which he could take with him; however, he found nothing but an old cheese, and that he put in his pocket. In front of the door he observed a bird which had caught itself in the thicket. It had to go into his pocket with the cheese. Now he took to the road boldly, and as he was light and nimble, he felt no fatigue. The road led him up a mountain, and when he had reached the highest point of it, there sat a powerful giant looking peacefully about him. The little tailor went bravely up, spoke to him, and said: ‘Good day, comrade, so you are sitting there overlooking the wide-spread world! I am just on my way thither, and want to try my luck. Have you any inclination to go with me?’ The giant looked contemptuously at the tailor, and said: ‘You ragamuffin! You miserable creature!’
‘Oh, indeed?’ answered the little tailor, and unbuttoned his coat, and showed the giant the girdle, ‘there may you read what kind of a man I am!’ The giant read: ‘Seven at one stroke,’ and thought that they had been men whom the tailor had killed, and began to feel a little respect for the tiny fellow. Nevertheless, he wished to try him first, and took a stone in his hand and squeezed it together so that water dropped out of it. ‘Do that likewise,’ said the giant, ‘if you have strength.’ ‘Is that all?’ said the tailor, ‘that is child’s play with us!’ and put his hand into his pocket, brought out the soft cheese, and pressed it until the liquid ran out of it. ‘Faith,’ said he, ‘that was a little better, wasn’t it?’ The giant did not know what to say, and could not believe it of the little man. Before long, he came upon a great forest, its towering trees casting long shadows across the path. Undaunted, the little tailor strode forward, his heart light with courage. But as he ventured deeper into the woods, he heard a rustling in the underbrush. Out sprang a fearsome giant, his massive frame blocking the way.  

"Ho there, little man!" boomed the giant, his voice like thunder. "What brings you to my forest?"  

The tailor, though small in stature, stood his ground. "I am traveling the world," he declared, "for my workshop was too cramped for my mighty deeds."  

The giant roared with laughter. "You? Mighty deeds? Why, I could crush you with one hand!"  

The tailor smiled slyly. "Is that so? Well, I wager I could squeeze water from this stone!" He pulled a lump of cheese from his pocket and, with a mighty squeeze, made the whey run through his fingers.  

The giant’s eyes widened. "Impossible!" he gasped.  

"Ah, but there’s more," said the tailor. "Watch this!" He took up a pebble and hurled it into the sky with such force that it never came down. (In truth, he had tossed a bird hidden in his palm, but the giant did not see.)  

The giant, now thoroughly impressed, stammered, "Perhaps you are stronger than you look. Come, let us be companions!"  

And so they traveled together, though the giant soon grew envious of the tailor’s cleverness. One night, as they camped beneath an ancient oak, the giant pointed to a cherry tree heavy with fruit. "Pluck us some cherries," he said, thinking to humble the little man.  

The tailor scrambled up the trunk, but as he reached for the fruit, the giant shook the tree violently, hoping to fling him off. Yet the tailor clung fast, pretending to enjoy the ride. "What fun!" he cried. "I’m swinging through the air like a bird!"  

Frustrated, the giant led him to a cave where his brothers slept. "Stay here tonight," he grumbled, then left, plotting to crush the tailor in his sleep. But the tailor, sensing treachery, crept to the far end of the cave and hid.  

At midnight, the giant returned with a club and brought it down upon the bed where he thought the tailor lay. "There! That’s the end of him!" he crowed.  

The next morning, the tailor strolled out, whistling as if nothing had happened. The giants, terrified of such an indestructible foe, fled into the wilderness, never to trouble him again.  

With a chuckle, the tailor continued his journey, his legend growing with each step. For though he was small, his wit was mighty—and in the end, that was the greatest strength of all.

events.title: A Night in the Giants' Cave and a Narrow Escape
detailed_summary: The giant, perhaps still partly convinced of the tailor's prowess, invites him to spend the night in the giants' cave.
The tailor agrees and follows him, observing that the cave, inhabited by other giants eating roasted sheep, is much larger than his workshop.
The giant directs him to a bed, but it is far too large for the tailor, who opts to sleep in a corner instead of lying in it.
Around midnight, the giant, believing the tailor is fast asleep in the bed, gets up and smashes the bed with a great iron bar, intending to kill the 'grasshopper'.
The following morning, as the giants prepare to go into the forest, having forgotten about the tailor, he suddenly appears before them, cheerful and bold.
The giants are utterly terrified, convinced he will kill them all, and they flee in a great hurry.

Feeling weary, he lies down on the grass and falls asleep.
While he sleeps, people from the palace gather and inspect him, noticing the inscription 'Seven at one stroke' on his girdle.
Interpreting this as a sign of a great warrior, they wonder about his presence in a time of peace and conclude he must be a mighty lord.
They report their findings to the king, suggesting that such a man would be invaluable if war were to break out and should not be allowed to leave.
The king is pleased with this counsel and dispatches one of his courtiers to offer the tailor military service when he awakens.
The courtier waits by the sleeping tailor, and upon the tailor waking and stretching, conveys the king's proposal.
The tailor replies that this was precisely his reason for coming and readily accepts the offer to enter the king's service.
Consequently, he is received with honor and assigned a special dwelling.

events.title: Envy, a Royal Dilemma, and the Task of Two Giants
detailed_summary: The king's soldiers quickly grow resentful of the little tailor, fearing his supposed ability to kill seven at a blow and feeling unable to stand against him if a quarrel arose.
They collectively approach the king and request their dismissal, stating they are unprepared to serve alongside such a formidable individual.
The king is dismayed at the thought of losing all his loyal servants for one man and regrets having encountered the tailor, wishing to be rid of him.
However, he dares not dismiss the tailor directly, fearing the tailor might kill him and his people and seize the throne.
After much thought, the king devises a plan. He summons the tailor and, acknowledging him as a great warrior, requests a service: to deal with two giants who cause immense destruction in a forest.
The king promises his only daughter in marriage and half his kingdom as a dowry if the tailor succeeds, also offering one hundred horsemen for assistance.
The tailor, seeing this as a magnificent opportunity, confidently accepts, boasting that he who can hit seven at one blow needs no help against two.
He sets off with the horsemen but tells them to wait at the forest's edge, claiming he will handle the giants alone.
Inside the forest, he finds both giants asleep under a tree, snoring loudly.
The tailor, having gathered two pockets full of stones, climbs the tree and positions himself above the sleeping giants.
He drops stones onto the chest of one giant, who awakens and accuses his companion of hitting him; the other denies it, and they go back to sleep.
The tailor then drops a stone on the second giant, who also wakes up and accuses the first of pelting him, leading to a dispute before they fall asleep again from weariness.
Finally, the tailor hurls his largest stone with all his might onto the chest of the first giant.
This giant springs up enraged and attacks his companion, and the two giants engage in a furious battle, tearing up trees and fighting until they both fall dead.
The tailor then descends, stabs each giant a few times with his sword, and returns to the horsemen, claiming a hard-fought victory where the giants defended themselves fiercely with uprooted trees.
