events.text_segment:
The soldiers, however, were set against the little tailor, and wished him a thousand miles away. ‘What is to be the end of this?’ they said among themselves. ‘If we quarrel with him, and he strikes about him, seven of us will fall at every blow; not one of us can stand against him.’ They came therefore to a decision, betook themselves in a body to the king, and begged for their dismissal. ‘We are not prepared,’ said they, ‘to stay with a man who kills seven at one stroke.’ The king was sorry that for the sake of one he should lose all his faithful servants, wished that he had never set eyes on the tailor, and would willingly have been rid of him again. But he did not venture to give him his dismissal, for he dreaded lest he should strike him and all his people dead, and place himself on the royal throne. He thought about it for a long time, and at last found good counsel. He sent to the little tailor and caused him to be informed that as he was a great warrior, he had one request to make to him. In a forest of his country lived two giants, who caused great mischief with their robbing, murdering, ravaging, and burning, and no one could approach them without putting himself in danger of death. If the tailor conquered and killed these two giants, he would give him his only daughter to wife, and half of his kingdom as a dowry, likewise one hundred horsemen should go with him to assist him. ‘That would indeed be a fine thing for a man like me!’ thought the little tailor. ‘One is not offered a beautiful princess and half a kingdom every day of one’s life!’ ‘Oh, yes,’ he replied, ‘I will soon subdue the giants, and do not require the help of the hundred horsemen to do it; he who can hit seven with one blow has no need to be afraid of two.’
The little tailor went forth, and the hundred horsemen followed him. When he came to the outskirts of the forest, he said to his followers: ‘Just stay waiting here, I alone will soon finish off the giants.’ Then he bounded into the forest and looked about right and left. After a while he perceived both giants. They lay sleeping under a tree, and snored so that the branches waved up and down. The little tailor, not idle, gathered two pocketsful of stones, and with these climbed up the tree. When he was halfway up, he slipped down by a branch, until he sat just above the sleepers, and then let one stone after another fall on the breast of one of the giants. For a long time the giant felt nothing, but at last he awoke, pushed his comrade, and said: ‘Why are you knocking me?’ ‘You must be dreaming,’ said the other, ‘I am not knocking you.’ They laid themselves down to sleep again, and then the tailor threw a stone down on the second. ‘What is the meaning of this?’ cried the other ‘Why are you pelting me?’ ‘I am not pelting you,’ answered the first, growling. They disputed about it for a time, but as they were weary they let the matter rest, and their eyes closed once more. The little tailor began his game again, picked out the biggest stone, and threw it with all his might on the breast of the first giant. ‘That is too bad!’ cried he, and sprang up like a madman, and pushed his companion against the tree until it shook. The other paid him back in the same coin, and they got into such a rage that they tore up trees and belaboured each other so long, that at last they both fell down dead on the ground at the same time. Then the little tailor leapt down. ‘It is a lucky thing,’ said he, ‘that they did not tear up the tree on which I was sitting, or I should have had to sprint on to another like a squirrel; but we tailors are nimble.’ He drew out his sword and gave each of them a couple of thrusts in the breast, and then went out to the horsemen and said: ‘The work is done; I have finished both of them off, but it was hard work! They tore up trees in their sore need, and defended themselves with them, but all that is to no purpose when a man like myself comes, who can kill seven at one blow.’ ‘But are you not wounded?’ asked the horsemen. ‘You need not concern yourself about that,’ answered the tailor, ‘they have not bent one hair of mine.’ The horsemen would not believe him, and rode into the forest; there they found the giants swimming in their blood, and all round about lay the torn-up trees.

The soldiers, however, were set against the little tailor, and wished him a thousand miles away. They grumbled among themselves, for they could not bear the thought of a mere stitcher of cloth rising above them in rank and favor. "What does the king see in him?" one muttered. "He's no warrior, only a braggart who got lucky with flies and giants!"  

The tailor, sharp as his needles, soon noticed their disdain. But instead of shrinking away, he met their scorn with a smile. "Good sirs," he said one evening as they gathered in the barracks, "if you doubt my courage, why not test it? I’ve bested giants—surely I can handle a few soldiers!"  

The men exchanged glances. Here was their chance to humble him. Their captain, a burly man with a scar across his cheek, stepped forward. "Very well, tailor. Tomorrow at dawn, we ride into the Black Forest. They say a fearsome beast dwells there—one that has slain many brave men. If you can slay it, we’ll acknowledge you as our better."  

The little tailor bowed. "Agreed!"  

That night, as the soldiers laughed over their ale, certain of his doom, the tailor sat by his window, stitching a new coat. He hummed to himself, for he had a plan.  

At dawn, the company rode out. The forest loomed dark and tangled before them. The soldiers halted at the edge. "We’ll wait here," the captain said smugly. "The beast’s lair lies straight ahead. Don’t keep us waiting too long—if you’re still alive."  

The tailor dismounted, patted his horse, and strode into the trees. He hadn’t gone far when he heard a low growl. From the shadows emerged a monstrous wolf, its eyes glowing like embers.  

"Ah, good morning!" the tailor said cheerfully. "You must be the beast I’ve heard so much about."  

The wolf snarled and lunged. Quick as a flash, the tailor sidestepped and whipped out his measuring tape. As the wolf turned for another attack, the tailor looped the tape around its neck and pulled tight. The beast thrashed, but the tailor held firm, tying the tape in a neat knot. The wolf gasped, collapsed—and lay still.  

"One less pest in the forest," the tailor said, dusting his hands. Then he noticed movement in the bushes. A second wolf, even larger, crept forward.  

The tailor sighed. "Must I do everything myself?" He reached into his pack and pulled out a large sausage—leftover from his breakfast. He tossed it to the wolf, who snapped it up greedily. But the tailor had laced the sausage with sleeping herbs. Within moments, the wolf yawned and slumped to the ground.  

Pleased, the tailor turned to leave—only to face a towering bear, its claws glinting.  

"Now this is getting ridiculous," the tailor muttered. But he was never without a trick. He pulled out a small mirror and angled it so the sunlight flashed into the bear’s eyes. Blinded, the beast roared and swiped at the air. The tailor darted behind a tree, then another, leading the bear in circles until it grew dizzy and crashed to the ground in exhaustion.  

With all three beasts subdued, the tailor returned to the waiting soldiers. They gaped as he strolled out of the forest, whistling.  

"Well?" he asked. "Satisfied?"  

The captain’s face darkened. "You expect us to believe you defeated the beasts so easily?"  

The tailor shrugged. "See for yourselves."  

Reluctantly, the soldiers ventured into the forest. There they found the wolf strangled, the second wolf snoring, and the bear groaning in a daze.  

The men had no choice but to admit defeat. From that day on, they treated the little tailor with wary respect. Even the king, upon hearing the tale, clapped his hands in delight. "Truly, you are the cleverest man in my kingdom!"  

And so the little tailor, once mocked and doubted, lived out his days in honor and peace—proving that wit and courage often triumph over brute strength.  

As for the soldiers? They never underestimated a tailor again.

events.title: The King's Reluctance: Capturing a Unicorn and a Wild Boar
detailed_summary: The tailor requests his promised reward from the king, but the king, regretting his pledge, devises another task for the 'hero'.
He tells the tailor that before receiving his daughter and half the kingdom, he must capture a destructive unicorn roaming the forest.
The tailor, undaunted, states he fears a unicorn even less than two giants, as 'Seven at one blow' is his specialty.
Taking a rope and an axe, he ventures into the forest, again instructing his escorts to wait outside.
He soon encounters the unicorn, which charges directly at him.
The tailor calmly waits until the unicorn is close, then nimbly springs behind a tree.
The unicorn, unable to stop, impales the tree with its horn, becoming stuck.
The tailor declares he has 'got the bird,' emerges, puts the rope around the unicorn's neck, hews its horn from the tree with his axe, and leads the captured beast to the king.
Still reluctant, the king makes a third demand: the tailor must catch a wild boar causing great havoc in the forest, with the assistance of royal huntsmen.
The tailor agrees, calling it 'child's play,' and again declines the huntsmen's help, much to their relief as they had previous unpleasant encounters with the boar.
When the boar spots the tailor, it charges with foaming mouth and whetted tusks.
The tailor flees into a nearby chapel, jumps up to a window, and leaps out.
The boar rushes into the chapel after him, whereupon the tailor quickly runs around the outside and shuts the door, trapping the enraged beast, which is too heavy to escape through the window.
He then summons the huntsmen to witness the captured boar.
The king, now with no further recourse, is compelled to honor his promise, giving the tailor his daughter and half the kingdom.
The narrative notes that had the king known he was dealing with a mere tailor rather than a warrior, his dismay would have been even greater.
A magnificent wedding is held, though with little joy, and thus, a tailor is made into a king.

The little tailor demanded of the king the promised reward; he, however, repented of his promise, and again bethought himself how he could get rid of the hero. ‘Before you receive my daughter, and the half of my kingdom,’ said he to him, ‘you must perform one more heroic deed. In the forest roams a unicorn which does great harm, and you must catch it first.’ ‘I fear one unicorn still less than two giants. Seven at one blow, is my kind of affair.’ He took a rope and an axe with him, went forth into the forest, and again bade those who were sent with him to wait outside. He had not long to seek. The unicorn soon came towards him, and rushed directly on the tailor, as if it would gore him with its horn without more ado. ‘Softly, softly; it can’t be done as quickly as that,’ said he, and stood still and waited until the animal was quite close, and then sprang nimbly behind the tree. The unicorn ran against the tree with all its strength, and stuck its horn so fast in the trunk that it had not the strength enough to draw it out again, and thus it was caught. ‘Now, I have got the bird,’ said the tailor, and came out from behind the tree and put the rope round its neck, and then with his axe he hewed the horn out of the tree, and when all was ready he led the beast away and took it to the king.
The king still would not give him the promised reward, and made a third demand. Before the wedding the tailor was to catch him a wild boar that made great havoc in the forest, and the huntsmen should give him their help. ‘Willingly,’ said the tailor, ‘that is child’s play!’ He did not take the huntsmen with him into the forest, and they were well pleased that he did not, for the wild boar had several times received them in such a manner that they had no inclination to lie in wait for him. When the boar perceived the tailor, it ran on him with foaming mouth and whetted tusks, and was about to throw him to the ground, but the hero fled and sprang into a chapel which was near and up to the window at once, and in one bound out again. The boar ran after him, but the tailor ran round outside and shut the door behind it, and then the raging beast, which was much too heavy and awkward to leap out of the window, was caught. The little tailor called the huntsmen thither that they might see the prisoner with their own eyes. The hero, however, went to the king, who was now, whether he liked it or not, obliged to keep his promise, and gave his daughter and the half of his kingdom. Had he known that it was no warlike hero, but a little tailor who was standing before him, it would have gone to his heart still more than it did. The wedding was held with great magnificence and small joy, and out of a tailor a king was made.

events.title: The Tailor King Outwits a Royal Plot and Secures His Reign
detailed_summary: Some time later, the young queen overhears her husband, the tailor-king, muttering in his sleep about tailoring tasks like making doublets and patching pantaloons.
From this, she deduces his humble origins and feels wronged.
The next morning, she complains to her father, the old king, and begs him to help her get rid of her husband, whom she now knows is merely a tailor.

The old king comforts her and outlines a plan: she is to leave her bedroom door open that night. His servants will wait outside, and once the tailor-king is asleep, they will enter, bind him, and transport him onto a ship to be carried far away.
The queen is satisfied with this arrangement.
However, the king's armour-bearer, who is friendly towards the young tailor-king, overhears the entire plot and informs him.
The tailor-king declares he will foil their plan.
That night, he goes to bed with his wife as usual. When she believes he has fallen asleep, she gets up, opens the bedroom door, and lies down again.
The tailor-king, who was only feigning sleep, begins to shout loudly and clearly, as if talking in his sleep or addressing unseen listeners.

He recounts his great feats: 'I smote seven at one blow. I killed two giants, I brought away one unicorn, and caught a wild boar,' and then rhetorically asks if he should now fear those standing outside his room.
The servants waiting outside, upon hearing the tailor-king's booming recitation of his supposed heroic deeds, are overcome with terror.
They flee as if pursued by a demonic hunter, and none dare to make any further attempt against him.
Thus, the little tailor successfully thwarts the plot and solidifies his position, remaining a king for the rest of his life.

events.title: The Parents' Desperate Plan to Abandon the Children
detailed_summary: A poor wood-cutter and his wife, living near a large forest, faced severe famine and struggled to provide even basic sustenance for themselves and their two children, Hansel and Gretel.
One night, consumed by worry, the wood-cutter lamented to his wife about their inability to feed the children.

The wife suggested a grim plan: to lead the children into the densest part of the forest the next morning, provide them with a last piece of bread and a fire, then abandon them at their work, ensuring they could not return.
The wood-cutter was initially aghast, expressing fear that wild animals would kill the children if left alone.
His wife dismissed his concerns, insisting that abandoning the children was the only alternative to all four of them starving, and she persisted until he reluctantly consented to her plan.
Despite his agreement, the wood-cutter confessed his profound sadness for the children's fate.

Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife: ‘What is to become of us? How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?’ ‘I’ll tell you what, husband,’ answered the woman, ‘early tomorrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest; there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one more piece of bread, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone. They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them.’ ‘No, wife,’ said the man, ‘I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest?—the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces.’ ‘O, you fool!’ said she, ‘then we must all four die of hunger, you may as well plane the planks for our coffins,’ and she left him no peace until he consented. ‘But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same,’ said the man.

Hard by a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children, a boy named Hansel and a girl called Gretel. They had little to eat, and in times of famine, even that little grew less. One evening, as the children lay in bed, the wood-cutter sighed deeply and said to his wife, "What is to become of us? How can we feed our poor little ones when we have nothing for ourselves?"

"Listen to me, husband," answered the wife, who was the children’s stepmother. "Early tomorrow, we will take the children deep into the forest, light a fire for them, give each a crust of bread, and leave them there. They will never find their way home, and we shall be rid of them."

The wood-cutter’s heart ached at the thought, but his wife would not relent. "If we do not," she said, "we shall all perish of hunger." 

Hansel and Gretel, who had not been able to sleep for hunger, overheard their stepmother’s cruel plan. Gretel wept bitterly, but Hansel whispered, "Do not cry, little sister. I will find a way to save us." 

When the moon rose, he crept outside and filled his pockets with white pebbles that glittered like silver in the moonlight. "These will guide us home," he said, comforted. 

The next morning, as the family set out into the forest, Hansel dropped the pebbles one by one along the path, unnoticed by his parents. And so, when they were abandoned, the children had only to follow the shining trail back to safety—for now.

events.title: Hansel's Pebble Trail and the First Forest Journey
detailed_summary: Unable to sleep due to hunger, Hansel and Gretel overheard their stepmother detailing the abandonment plan to their father.
Gretel was overcome with despair, crying bitterly, but Hansel urged her to be calm, assuring her he would devise a way to save them.
After their parents fell asleep, Hansel slipped outside, where the bright moonlight illuminated white pebbles in front of their house.
He gathered as many pebbles as he could fit into his coat pocket.
Returning to Gretel, he comforted her, telling her to trust in God, and then went back to bed.
At dawn, before sunrise, the stepmother woke the children, announcing their trip to the forest to gather wood.
She gave each child a small piece of bread for dinner, warning them not to eat it beforehand.
Gretel hid her bread under her apron, while Hansel had his pebbles.
As they walked, Hansel repeatedly paused to look back, explaining to his concerned father that he was bidding farewell to his white cat on the roof.
The stepmother chided him, saying it was merely the morning sun on the chimney, unaware that Hansel was actually dropping pebbles to mark their path.

When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said: ‘Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold.’ Hansel and Gretel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill. The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said: ‘Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood. When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away.’
Hansel and Gretel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near. It was not the axe, however, but a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards. And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes closed with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep. When at last they awoke, it was already dark night. Gretel began to cry and said: ‘How are we to get out of the forest now?’ But Hansel comforted her and said: ‘Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way.’ And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.
They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father’s house. They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Gretel, she said: ‘You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest?—we thought you were never coming back at all!’ The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.

  The heaven-born wind,’

Gretel, however, ran like lightning to Hansel, opened his little stable, and cried: ‘Hansel, we are saved! The old witch is dead!’ Then Hansel sprang like a bird from its cage when the door is opened. How they did rejoice and embrace each other, and dance about and kiss each other! And as they had no longer any need to fear her, they went into the witch’s house, and in every corner there stood chests full of pearls and jewels. ‘These are far better than pebbles!’ said Hansel, and thrust into his pockets whatever could be got in, and Gretel said: ‘I, too, will take something home with me,’ and filled her pinafore full. ‘But now we must be off,’ said Hansel, ‘that we may get out of the witch’s forest.’
When they had walked for two hours, they came to a great stretch of water. ‘We cannot cross,’ said Hansel, ‘I see no foot-plank, and no bridge.’ ‘And there is also no ferry,’ answered Gretel, ‘but a white duck is swimming there: if I ask her, she will help us over.’ Then she cried:
‘Little duck, little duck, dost thou see,
  Hansel and Gretel are waiting for thee?
  There’s never a plank, or bridge in sight,
  Take us across on thy back so white.’
The duck came to them, and Hansel seated himself on its back, and told his sister to sit by him. ‘No,’ replied Gretel, ‘that will be too heavy for the little duck; she shall take us across, one after the other.’ The good little duck did so, and when they were once safely across and had walked for a short time, the forest seemed to be more and more familiar to them, and at length they saw from afar their father’s house. Then they began to run, rushed into the parlour, and threw themselves round their father’s neck. The man had not known one happy hour since he had left the children in the forest; the woman, however, was dead. Gretel emptied her pinafore until pearls and precious stones ran about the room, and Hansel threw one handful after another out of his pocket to add to them. Then all anxiety was at an end, and they lived together in perfect happiness. My tale is done, there runs a mouse; whosoever catches it, may make himself a big fur cap out of it.

The old woman's kind tone reassured the girl, who then found the courage to accept the offer and enter Mother Holle's service.

A huntsman passing by the house heard the loud snoring and thought the old woman might need assistance, deciding to investigate.
Upon entering the room and approaching the bed, he discovered the wolf lying there.
The huntsman recognized the wolf as an 'old sinner' he had been pursuing for a long time.
He was about to shoot the wolf when he considered that the wolf might have consumed the grandmother, who could potentially still be alive and rescued.
Therefore, he refrained from shooting and instead used a pair of scissors to carefully cut open the sleeping wolf's stomach.
After making two cuts, he saw Little Red-Cap. With two more snips, the little girl jumped out, exclaiming how terrified she had been and how dark it was inside the wolf.
Following her, the elderly grandmother also emerged alive, though she was very weak and struggled to breathe.

He said to himself, ‘I will give her to the first suitable man who comes and asks for her hand.’ Not long after a suitor appeared, and as he appeared to be very rich and the miller could see nothing in him with which to find fault, he betrothed his daughter to him. But the girl did not care for the man as a girl ought to care for her betrothed husband. She did not feel that she could trust him, and she could not look at him nor think of him without an inward shudder. detailed_summary: The girl proceeded through the house, exploring its rooms, all of which were empty, and she still encountered no one.

The girl passed on, going from room to room of the house, but they were all empty, and still she saw no one. At last she came to the cellar, and there sat a very, very old woman, who could not keep her head from shaking. ‘Can you tell me,’ asked the girl, ‘if my betrothed husband lives here?’
‘Ah, you poor child,’ answered the old woman, ‘what a place for you to come to! This is a murderers’ den. You think yourself a promised bride, and that your marriage will soon take place, but it is with death that you will keep your marriage feast. Look, do you see that large cauldron of water which I am obliged to keep on the fire! As soon as they have you in their power they will kill you without mercy, and cook and eat you, for they are eaters of men. If I did not take pity on you and save you, you would be lost.’
Thereupon the old woman led her behind a large cask, which quite hid her from view. ‘Keep as still as a mouse,’ she said; ‘do not move or speak, or it will be all over with you. Tonight, when the robbers are all asleep, we will flee together. I have long been waiting for an opportunity to escape.’

events.title: The Bride's Chilling Tale at the Wedding Feast
detailed_summary: The day appointed for the wedding arrived; the bridegroom attended, along with a large assembly of guests whom the miller had invited from his friends and relations.
As they were seated at the feast, each guest, in turn, was prompted to tell a story; the bride, however, sat still and remained silent.
The bridegroom, turning to her, inquired if she knew no tale and urged her to share something.
The bride responded that she would recount a dream.

She began her tale, describing going alone through a forest until she reached a house where she found no one, except for a bird in a cage on the wall that cried out twice: 'Turn back, turn back, young maiden fair, Linger not in this murderers’ lair.'
The bridegroom interjected, remarking, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'

She continued her narrative, describing her exploration of the empty, grim, and mysterious house, eventually going down to the cellar where she found a very old woman who revealed that her betrothed lived there but intended to kill, cook, and eat her.
Again, the bridegroom dismissed it with, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'

The bride detailed how the old woman hid her behind a large cask, the robbers' subsequent return dragging another young girl, and how they gave the girl three kinds of wine—white, red, and yellow—causing her death.
The bridegroom once more stated, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'
She then described how the robbers tore off the dead girl's clothing, cut her body into pieces, and sprinkled salt upon it.
For the fourth time, the bridegroom said, 'My darling, this is only a dream.'

A poor woodman sat in his cottage one night, smoking his pipe by the fireside, while his wife sat by his side spinning. ‘How lonely it is, wife,’ said he, as he puffed out a long curl of smoke, ‘for you and me to sit here by ourselves, without any children to play about and amuse us while other people seem so happy and merry with their children!’ ‘What you say is very true,’ said the wife, sighing, and turning round her wheel; ‘how happy should I be if I had but one child! If it were ever so small—nay, if it were no bigger than my thumb—I should be very happy, and love it dearly.’ Now—odd as you may think it—it came to pass that this good woman’s wish was fulfilled, just in the very way she had wished it; for, not long afterwards, she had a little boy, who was quite healthy and strong, but was not much bigger than my thumb. So they said, ‘Well, we cannot say we have not got what we wished for, and, little as he is, we will love him dearly.’ And they called him Thomas Thumb.
They gave him plenty of food, yet for all they could do he never grew bigger, but kept just the same size as he had been when he was born. Still, his eyes were sharp and sparkling, and he soon showed himself to be a clever little fellow, who always knew well what he was about.

One day, as the woodman was getting ready to go into the wood to cut fuel, he said, ‘I wish I had someone to bring the cart after me, for I want to make haste.’ ‘Oh, father,’ cried Tom, ‘I will take care of that; the cart shall be in the wood by the time you want it.’ Then the woodman laughed, and said, ‘How can that be? you cannot reach up to the horse’s bridle.’ ‘Never mind that, father,’ said Tom; ‘if my mother will only harness the horse, I will get into his ear and tell him which way to go.’ ‘Well,’ said the father, ‘we will try for once.’
When the time came the mother harnessed the horse to the cart, and put Tom into his ear; and as he sat there the little man told the beast how to go, crying out, ‘Go on!’ and ‘Stop!’ as he wanted: and thus the horse went on just as well as if the woodman had driven it himself into the wood. It happened that as the horse was going a little too fast, and Tom was calling out, ‘Gently! gently!’ two strangers came up. ‘What an odd thing that is!’ said one: ‘there is a cart going along, and I hear a carter talking to the horse, but yet I can see no one.’ ‘That is queer, indeed,’ said the other; ‘let us follow the cart, and see where it goes.’ So they went on into the wood, till at last they came to the place where the woodman was. Then Tom Thumb, seeing his father, cried out, ‘See, father, here I am with the cart, all right and safe! now take me down!’ So his father took hold of the horse with one hand, and with the other took his son out of the horse’s ear, and put him down upon a straw, where he sat as merry as you please.

events.text_segment:
The two strangers were all this time looking on, and did not know what to say for wonder. At last one took the other aside, and said, ‘That little urchin will make our fortune, if we can get him, and carry him about from town to town as a show; we must buy him.’ So they went up to the woodman, and asked him what he would take for the little man. ‘He will be better off,’ said they, ‘with us than with you.’ ‘I won’t sell him at all,’ said the father; ‘my own flesh and blood is dearer to me than all the silver and gold in the world.’ But Tom, hearing of the bargain they wanted to make, crept up his father’s coat to his shoulder and whispered in his ear, ‘Take the money, father, and let them have me; I’ll soon come back to you.’
So the woodman at last said he would sell Tom to the strangers for a large piece of gold, and they paid the price. ‘Where would you like to sit?’ said one of them. ‘Oh, put me on the rim of your hat; that will be a nice gallery for me; I can walk about there and see the country as we go along.’ So they did as he wished; and when Tom had taken leave of his father they took him away with them.
They journeyed on till it began to be dusky, and then the little man said, ‘Let me get down, I’m tired.’ So the man took off his hat, and put him down on a clod of earth, in a ploughed field by the side of the road. But Tom ran about amongst the furrows, and at last slipped into an old mouse-hole. ‘Good night, my masters!’ said he, ‘I’m off! mind and look sharp after me the next time.’ Then they ran at once to the place, and poked the ends of their sticks into the mouse-hole, but all in vain; Tom only crawled farther and farther in; and at last it became quite dark, so that they were forced to go their way without their prize, as sulky as could be.

events.title: Tom's Encounter with Thieves and Foiling of a Robbery
detailed_summary: Once the strangers had departed, Tom emerged from his hiding place, remarking on the perilous nature of walking in the ploughed field due to the large clods of earth.
Fortunately, he discovered a large, empty snail-shell, which he deemed a lucky find suitable for sleeping in, and crept inside.
Just as he was drifting off to sleep, he overheard two men passing by, discussing how they might rob a rich parson of his silver and gold.
Tom cried out, offering to tell them how.
The thieves were startled, one exclaiming he was sure he heard someone speak.
They paused, listening, and Tom spoke again, suggesting they take him along and he would show them how to acquire the parson's money.
When they asked his whereabouts, he instructed them to search the ground and listen for the sound of his voice.
Eventually, the thieves found him and lifted him up, skeptically asking what such a tiny creature could do for them.
Tom explained he could slip between the iron window-bars of the parson's house and throw out whatever they desired.
The thieves considered this a good idea and decided to take him with them to see what he could do.
Upon reaching the parson's house, Tom slipped through the window-bars into a room.
He then shouted at the top of his voice, asking if the thieves wanted everything within the room.
This frightened the thieves, who urged him to speak softly to avoid waking anyone.
Tom, pretending not to understand, bellowed again, asking how much they wanted and if he should throw everything out.
The cook, sleeping in an adjoining room, heard the noise, sat up in bed, and listened intently.
Meanwhile, the thieves, terrified, retreated a short distance but then, gathering courage, decided Tom was merely trying to trick them.
They returned and whispered to him to stop his pranks and throw out some money.
Tom then shouted as loudly as possible, announcing, 'Very well! hold your hands! here it comes.'
The cook heard this clearly, so she jumped out of bed and ran to open the door.
The thieves fled as if a wolf were chasing them.
The maid, after searching the room and finding nothing, went to fetch a light.
By the time she returned, Tom had managed to slip away into the barn.
After the maid had thoroughly searched every nook and cranny without finding anyone, she went back to bed, believing she must have been dreaming while awake.
The little man crawled about in the hay-loft and eventually found a comfortable spot to rest for the night, intending to sleep until daylight and then make his way home to his parents.

When Tom found they were gone, he came out of his hiding-place. ‘What dangerous walking it is,’ said he, ‘in this ploughed field! If I were to fall from one of these great clods, I should undoubtedly break my neck.’ At last, by good luck, he found a large empty snail-shell. ‘This is lucky,’ said he, ‘I can sleep here very well’; and in he crept.
Just as he was falling asleep, he heard two men passing by, chatting together; and one said to the other, ‘How can we rob that rich parson’s house of his silver and gold?’ ‘I’ll tell you!’ cried Tom. ‘What noise was that?’ said the thief, frightened; ‘I’m sure I heard someone speak.’ They stood still listening, and Tom said, ‘Take me with you, and I’ll soon show you how to get the parson’s money.’ ‘But where are you?’ said they. ‘Look about on the ground,’ answered he, ‘and listen where the sound comes from.’ At last the thieves found him out, and lifted him up in their hands. ‘You little urchin!’ they said, ‘what can you do for us?’ ‘Why, I can get between the iron window-bars of the parson’s house, and throw you out whatever you want.’ ‘That’s a good thought,’ said the thieves; ‘come along, we shall see what you can do.’
When they came to the parson’s house, Tom slipped through the window-bars into the room, and then called out as loud as he could bawl, ‘Will you have all that is here?’ At this the thieves were frightened, and said, ‘Softly, softly! Speak low, that you may not awaken anybody.’ But Tom seemed as if he did not understand them, and bawled out again, ‘How much will you have? Shall I throw it all out?’ Now the cook lay in the next room; and hearing a noise she raised herself up in her bed and listened. Meantime the thieves were frightened, and ran off a little way; but at last they plucked up their hearts, and said, ‘The little urchin is only trying to make fools of us.’ So they came back and whispered softly to him, saying, ‘Now let us have no more of your roguish jokes; but throw us out some of the money.’ Then Tom called out as loud as he could, ‘Very well! hold your hands! here it comes.’
The cook heard this quite plain, so she sprang out of bed, and ran to open the door. The thieves ran off as if a wolf was at their tails: and the maid, having groped about and found nothing, went away for a light. By the time she came back, Tom had slipped off into the barn; and when she had looked about and searched every hole and corner, and found nobody, she went to bed, thinking she must have been dreaming with her eyes open.
The little man crawled about in the hay-loft, and at last found a snug place to finish his night’s rest in; so he laid himself down, meaning to sleep till daylight, and then find his way home to his father and mother.

events.title: Swallowed by a Wolf, Ingenious Trickery, and Miraculous Rescue
detailed_summary: Tom immediately began working to free himself from the cow's stomach, a task that proved difficult.
Just as he had managed to create enough space to get his head out, another misfortune befell him.
A hungry wolf appeared, swallowed the entire stomach with Tom inside in a single gulp, and then ran off.
Tom, however, remained undaunted. Believing the wolf might enjoy a conversation, he called out, offering to show his 'good friend' a fantastic treat.
When the wolf inquired about its location, Tom described his own father's house.

He provided specific instructions on how the wolf could crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, where it would find an abundance of delicacies like cakes, ham, beef, and more.
The wolf needed no second invitation and that very night, it went to the house, entered as Tom had described, and feasted to its satisfaction.
When it had eaten its fill and tried to leave, it discovered it had consumed so much that it could no longer fit back through the drain.
This was precisely what Tom had anticipated. He then began to shout and make as much noise as possible.
The wolf begged him to be quiet, warning that he would wake everyone in the house.
Tom retorted defiantly, stating that since the wolf had enjoyed its frolic, he now intended to be merry himself, and he continued to sing and shout at the top of his lungs.
The woodman and his wife, awakened by the commotion, peeked through a crack in the door and were terrified to see a wolf.
The woodman fetched his axe, and his wife a scythe.
The woodman instructed his wife to stay behind and, after he had struck the wolf on the head, she was to cut it open with the scythe.
Tom heard these instructions and cried out, 'Father, father! I am here, the wolf has swallowed me.'
His father, overjoyed, exclaimed that they had found their dear child again and told his wife not to use the scythe for fear of harming Tom.
The woodman then aimed a powerful blow at the wolf's head, killing it instantly.
Once the wolf was dead, they cut open its body and freed Tommy.
The father expressed the great fears they had experienced for Tom's safety.
Tom replied that he felt he had traveled all over the world in various ways since they last parted, and he was now very glad to be home and breathe fresh air again.
When his father asked where he had been, Tom recounted his adventures: in a mouse-hole, a snail-shell, down a cow's throat, and inside a wolf's belly, yet he had returned safe and sound.

events.title: Rumpelstiltskin Revealed and His Furious Demise
detailed_summary: Upon hearing the name 'Rumpelstiltskin', the queen leaped with joy.
As soon as her diminutive visitor arrived, she seated herself on her throne and summoned her entire court to witness the unfolding events, seemingly for amusement.
The nurse stood beside her, holding the baby as if fully prepared to surrender him.
The little man began to chuckle, anticipating taking the child to his woodland hut.
He then triumphantly asked, 'Now, lady, what is my name?'
The queen playfully offered incorrect guesses such as 'Is it JOHN?' and 'Is it TOM?', then 'Is it JEMMY?', all of which he denied.
Then, with a sly demeanor, she inquired, 'Can your name be RUMPELSTILTSKIN?'
The little man, utterly astonished and enraged, cried out that a witch must have revealed his name.
In his fury, he stamped his right foot so forcefully into the floor that it became stuck, requiring him to use both hands to pull it free.
He then departed as swiftly as possible, while the nurse laughed, the baby cooed, and the entire court jeered at him for his fruitless efforts.
They mockingly wished him a good morning and a merry feast, addressing him as 'Mr RUMPLESTILTSKIN!'

detailed_summary: The master instructs Gretel to prepare two fowls with great care for an evening guest.

The fowls began to turn brown, and were nearly ready, but the guest had not yet arrived. Then Gretel called out to her master: ‘If the guest does not come, I must take the fowls away from the fire, but it will be a sin and a shame if they are not eaten the moment they are at their juiciest.’ The master said: ‘I will run myself, and fetch the guest.’ When the master had turned his back, Gretel laid the spit with the fowls on one side, and thought: ‘Standing so long by the fire there, makes one sweat and thirsty; who knows when they will come? Meanwhile, I will run into the cellar, and take a drink.’ She ran down, set a jug, said: ‘God bless it for you, Gretel,’ and took a good drink, and thought that wine should flow on, and should not be interrupted, and took yet another hearty draught.

detailed_summary: An elderly man experienced significant physical decline, including dimmed vision, hearing loss, trembling knees, and difficulty eating without spilling.

The young wife verbally reprimanded him for this, but he only responded with a sigh of resignation.
As a replacement, they provided him with a cheap wooden bowl from which he had to eat his meals.

There was once a very old man, whose eyes had become dim, his ears dull of hearing, his knees trembled, and when he sat at table he could hardly hold the spoon, and spilt the broth upon the table-cloth or let it run out of his mouth. They were once sitting thus when the little grandson of four years old began to gather together some bits of wood upon the ground. ‘What are you doing there?’ asked the father. ‘I am making a little trough,’ answered the child, ‘for father and mother to eat out of when I am big.’  

The man and his wife looked at each other for a while, and presently began to cry. Then they took the old grandfather to the table, and henceforth always let him eat with them, and likewise said nothing if he did spill a little of anything.

Severe weather, including a storm of rain and wind, prevented him from continuing his journey, forcing him to turn back to the mill to ask for shelter.

events.text_segment:
And now the little peasant and his wife had the cow for which they had so long wished, and they were heartily glad, but they had no food for it, and could give it nothing to eat, so it soon had to be killed. They salted the flesh, and the peasant went into the town and wanted to sell the skin there, so that he might buy a new calf with the proceeds. On the way he passed by a mill, and there sat a raven with broken wings, and out of pity he took him and wrapped him in the skin. But as the weather grew so bad and there was a storm of rain and wind, he could go no farther, and turned back to the mill and begged for shelter. The miller’s wife was alone in the house, and said to the peasant: ‘Lay yourself on the straw there,’ and gave him a slice of bread and cheese. The peasant ate it, and lay down with his skin beside him, and the woman thought: ‘He is tired and has gone to sleep.’ In the meantime came the parson; the miller’s wife received him well, and said: ‘My husband is out, so we will have a feast.’ The peasant listened, and when he heard them talk about feasting he was vexed that he had been forced to make shift with a slice of bread and cheese. Then the woman served up four different things, roast meat, salad, cakes, and wine.
Just as they were about to sit down and eat, there was a knocking outside. The woman said: ‘Oh, heavens! It is my husband!’ she quickly hid the roast meat inside the tiled stove, the wine under the pillow, the salad on the bed, the cakes under it, and the parson in the closet on the porch. Then she opened the door for her husband, and said: ‘Thank heaven, you are back again! There is such a storm, it looks as if the world were coming to an end.’ The miller saw the peasant lying on the straw, and asked, ‘What is that fellow doing there?’ ‘Ah,’ said the wife, ‘the poor knave came in the storm and rain, and begged for shelter, so I gave him a bit of bread and cheese, and showed him where the straw was.’ The man said: ‘I have no objection, but be quick and get me something to eat.’ The woman said: ‘But I have nothing but bread and cheese.’ ‘I am contented with anything,’ replied the husband, ‘so far as I am concerned, bread and cheese will do,’ and looked at the peasant and said: ‘Come and eat some more with me.’ The peasant did not require to be invited twice, but got up and ate. After this the miller saw the skin in which the raven was, lying on the ground, and asked: ‘What have you there?’ The peasant answered: ‘I have a soothsayer inside it.’ ‘Can he foretell anything to me?’ said the miller. ‘Why not?’ answered the peasant: ‘but he only says four things, and the fifth he keeps to himself.’ The miller was curious, and said: ‘Let him foretell something for once.’ Then the peasant pinched the raven’s head, so that he croaked and made a noise like krr, krr. The miller said: ‘What did he say?’ The peasant answered: ‘In the first place, he says that there is some wine hidden under the pillow.’ ‘Bless me!’ cried the miller, and went there and found the wine. ‘Now go on,’ said he. The peasant made the raven croak again, and said: ‘In the second place, he says that there is some roast meat in the tiled stove.’ ‘Upon my word!’ cried the miller, and went thither, and found the roast meat. The peasant made the raven prophesy still more, and said: ‘Thirdly, he says that there is some salad on the bed.’ ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and went there and found the salad. At last the peasant pinched the raven once more till he croaked, and said: ‘Fourthly, he says that there are some cakes under the bed.’ ‘That would be a fine thing!’ cried the miller, and looked there, and found the cakes.

One evening, he crept to the peasant’s door and peered through the window. To his astonishment, he saw the peasant counting not gold, but simple copper coins—yet his house gleamed as if built by magic.  

The next day, the mayor demanded an explanation. The peasant smiled slyly and said, "I traded my cow for a handful of beans, and they grew into a vine that reached the clouds. There, I found a land where thrift and hard work are the only treasures."  

The mayor scoffed, but the peasant’s wisdom spread, and soon the villagers learned that true wealth lies not in golden snow, but in honest labor. And so, the small peasant lived happily, his house a testament to patience and cunning.

Consequently, the entire crowd of peasants plunged into the water after him, as a single group.

events.title: Catherine's Culinary Catastrophes and Cleanup
detailed_summary: Frederick requested his wife, Catherine, to prepare a good meal and ale for his return from working in the fields.
Catherine started frying their only steak and then went to the cellar to fetch ale.
While tapping the ale, she worried that the unsecured dog might steal the cooking steak.
Her fear materialized; she rushed upstairs to find the dog escaping with the steak in its mouth.
Catherine pursued the dog across a field but failed to retrieve the meat, eventually giving up and returning home tired.
Upon her return, she discovered that the ale tap had been left open, causing the entire cask to empty onto the cellar floor.
To manage the spillage, Catherine decided to use a sack of fine meal to absorb the ale.
In her attempt to apply the solution, she accidentally knocked over the jug of ale she had initially collected, adding to the mess.
She then spread the meal all over the cellar floor, feeling pleased with how clean and neat it looked despite the series of mishaps.
When Frederick arrived and asked for his dinner, Catherine recounted the loss of the steak to the dog, the spillage of all the ale, and how the meal was used to clean up the cellar.
Frederick questioned her choices, and Catherine defended herself by stating she was unaware she was doing anything wrong as he had not previously instructed her otherwise.

There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married. One day Frederick said. ‘Kate! I am going to work in the fields; when I come back I shall be hungry so let me have something nice cooked, and a good draught of ale.’ ‘Very well,’ said she, ‘it shall all be ready.’ When dinner-time drew nigh, Catherine took a nice steak, which was all the meat she had, and put it on the fire to fry. The steak soon began to look brown, and to crackle in the pan; and Catherine stood by with a fork and turned it: then she said to herself, ‘The steak is almost ready, I may as well go to the cellar for the ale.’ So she left the pan on the fire and took a large jug and went into the cellar and tapped the ale cask. The beer ran into the jug and Catherine stood looking on. At last it popped into her head, ‘The dog is not shut up—he may be running away with the steak; that’s well thought of.’ So up she ran from the cellar; and sure enough the rascally cur had got the steak in his mouth, and was making off with it.
Away ran Catherine, and away ran the dog across the field: but he ran faster than she, and stuck close to the steak. ‘It’s all gone, and “what can’t be cured must be endured”,’ said Catherine. So she turned round; and as she had run a good way and was tired, she walked home leisurely to cool herself.
Now all this time the ale was running too, for Catherine had not turned the cock; and when the jug was full the liquor ran upon the floor till the cask was empty. When she got to the cellar stairs she saw what had happened. ‘My stars!’ said she, ‘what shall I do to keep Frederick from seeing all this slopping about?’ So she thought a while; and at last remembered that there was a sack of fine meal bought at the last fair, and that if she sprinkled this over the floor it would suck up the ale nicely. ‘What a lucky thing,’ said she, ‘that we kept that meal! we have now a good use for it.’ So away she went for it: but she managed to set it down just upon the great jug full of beer, and upset it; and thus all the ale that had been saved was set swimming on the floor also. ‘Ah! well,’ said she, ‘when one goes another may as well follow.’ Then she strewed the meal all about the cellar, and was quite pleased with her cleverness, and said, ‘How very neat and clean it looks!’

There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married. One day, Frederick said to her, "Catherine, I must go into the fields to work. When I return, I should like something good to eat—something hot and hearty to warm my bones."  

Catherine, eager to please her new husband, replied, "Of course, dear Frederick! I shall prepare the finest meal for you."  

So Frederick went off to the fields, and Catherine set about cooking. She decided to make a rich stew, full of meat and vegetables. But as she stirred the pot, she grew curious. "I wonder how this tastes," she murmured to herself. She took a spoonful and found it delicious. "Just one more bite," she said, and soon, spoonful after spoonful, she had eaten nearly half the stew!  

Horrified at what she had done, Catherine thought quickly. "I must replace what I’ve eaten!" She ran to the cellar and fetched a jug of cream, pouring it into the pot to fill it up again. Then she tasted it once more—just to be sure it was good—and before she knew it, she had eaten another portion!  

Desperate, she added water, then flour, then scraps of bread, but each time she tasted it, she could not resist eating more. By the time Frederick returned, the pot was nearly empty.  

Frederick, tired and hungry, sat down at the table. "Bring me my supper, Catherine!" he called. Trembling, she placed the thin, watery broth before him. He took one sip and frowned. "What is this? I asked for a hearty meal!"  

Catherine, ashamed, confessed, "I tasted it, and it was so good I couldn’t stop! I tried to fix it, but—"  

Frederick, though annoyed, could not stay angry at his foolish wife. "Very well," he sighed. "But tomorrow, you must do better."  

The next day, Frederick went to the fields again, warning Catherine not to eat his food this time. She promised, but as soon as he left, she thought, "Surely a little taste won’t hurt."  

This time, she baked a fine loaf of bread. The smell was irresistible. She broke off a corner—just to test it—then another, and another, until half the loaf was gone! Panicked, she took the remaining bread and pressed it flat to make it look whole.  

When Frederick returned, he saw the flattened loaf and demanded, "Catherine, what happened to the bread?"  

She stammered, "It must have shrunk in the oven!"  

Frederick shook his head. "Wife, you are too greedy. If this continues, we shall starve!"  

Determined to teach her a lesson, Frederick pretended to leave for work the next day but hid outside the house. Sure enough, as soon as he was "gone," Catherine took out a wheel of cheese and began nibbling. Frederick burst in, shouting, "Aha! Caught you!"

‘Yellow buttons!’ said they; ‘let us see them.’

‘See, dear Frederick,’ said she, ‘I have bought all these with your yellow buttons; and I did not touch them myself; the pedlars dug them up themselves.’  

‘Ah, wife,’ said he, ‘what a pretty piece of work you have made! those were not buttons, but pure gold, and all that we had in the world; how could you be so silly?’  

‘Dear Frederick,’ said she, ‘why did you not tell me so before? I am sure I should never have thought of such a thing.’

Catherine stood musing for a while, and at last said to her husband, ‘Hark ye, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back: let us run after the thieves.’ ‘Well, we will try,’ answered he; ‘but take some butter and cheese with you, that we may have something to eat by the way.’ ‘Very well,’ said she; and they set out: and as Frederick walked the fastest, he left his wife some way behind. ‘It does not matter,’ thought she: ‘when we turn back, I shall be so much nearer home than he.’
Presently she came to the top of a hill, down the side of which there was a road so narrow that the cart wheels always chafed the trees on each side as they passed. ‘Ah, see now,’ said she, ‘how they have bruised and wounded those poor trees; they will never get well.’ So she took pity on them, and made use of the butter to grease them all, so that the wheels might not hurt them so much. While she was doing this kind office one of her cheeses fell out of the basket, and rolled down the hill. Catherine looked, but could not see where it had gone; so she said, ‘Well, I suppose the other will go the same way and find you; he has younger legs than I have.’ Then she rolled the other cheese after it; and away it went, nobody knows where, down the hill. But she said she supposed that they knew the road, and would follow her, and she could not stay there all day waiting for them.
At last she overtook Frederick, who desired her to give him something to eat. Then she gave him the dry bread. ‘Where are the butter and cheese?’ said he. ‘Oh!’ answered she, ‘I used the butter to grease those poor trees that the wheels chafed so: and one of the cheeses ran away so I sent the other after it to find it, and I suppose they are both on the road together somewhere.’ ‘What a goose you are to do such silly things!’ said the husband. ‘How can you say so?’ said she; ‘I am sure you never told me not.’

I sent you to make the house fast, and you take the door away, so that everybody may go in and out as they please—however, as you have brought the door, you shall carry it about with you for your pains.’ ‘Very well,’ answered she, ‘I’ll carry the door; but I’ll not carry the nuts and vinegar bottle also—that would be too much of a load; so if you please, I’ll fasten them to the door.’

Frederick of course made no objection to that plan, and they set off into the wood to look for the thieves; but they could not find them: and when it grew dark, they climbed up into a tree to spend the night there. Scarcely were they up, than who should come by but the very rogues they were looking for. They were in truth great rascals, and belonged to that class of people who find things before they are lost; they were tired; so they sat down and made a fire under the very tree where Frederick and Catherine were. Frederick slipped down on the other side, and picked up some stones. Then he climbed up again, and tried to hit the thieves on the head with them: but they only said, ‘It must be near morning, for the wind shakes the fir-apples down.’
Catherine, who had the door on her shoulder, began to be very tired; but she thought it was the nuts upon it that were so heavy: so she said softly, ‘Frederick, I must let the nuts go.’ ‘No,’ answered he, ‘not now, they will discover us.’ ‘I can’t help that: they must go.’ ‘Well, then, make haste and throw them down, if you will.’ Then away rattled the nuts down among the boughs and one of the thieves cried, ‘Bless me, it is hailing.’
A little while after, Catherine thought the door was still very heavy: so she whispered to Frederick, ‘I must throw the vinegar down.’ ‘Pray don’t,’ answered he, ‘it will discover us.’ ‘I can’t help that,’ said she, ‘go it must.’ So she poured all the vinegar down; and the thieves said, ‘What a heavy dew there is!’
At last it popped into Catherine’s head that it was the door itself that was so heavy all the time: so she whispered, ‘Frederick, I must throw the door down soon.’ But he begged and prayed her not to do so, for he was sure it would betray them. ‘Here goes, however,’ said she: and down went the door with such a clatter upon the thieves, that they cried out ‘Murder!’ and not knowing what was coming, ran away as fast as they could, and left all the gold. So when Frederick and Catherine came down, there they found all their money safe and sound.

The faithful maiden, upon hearing this, was overcome with sadness, feeling her heart might break, and did not want to go.
However, the other girls came and compelled her to attend.
When it was her turn to sing, she held back until she was the very last one remaining and could no longer refuse.
As she began her song, the sound reached Roland's ears.
He immediately jumped up, exclaiming that he recognized the voice as that of his true bride and that he would marry no other.
All his forgotten memories of her and their past together suddenly returned to his heart.

events.title: Snowdrop's Prophetic Birth and the Vain Queen's Introduction
detailed_summary: A queen, while sewing by an ebony window in winter, pricks her finger, and three drops of blood fall on the snow.
She expresses a wish for a daughter with skin as white as snow, lips as red as blood, and hair as black as ebony.
Her daughter, named Snowdrop, is subsequently born with these exact physical characteristics.
After some time, the original queen passes away.
The king takes a new wife, who is very beautiful but exceedingly vain and cannot tolerate the idea of anyone being more attractive than her.
This new queen possesses a magical looking-glass.
She regularly consults her mirror, inquiring who is the most beautiful woman in the realm.
The mirror consistently reassures her that she, the queen, holds the title of the fairest.

events.text_segment:
It was the middle of winter, when the broad flakes of snow were falling around, that the queen of a country many thousand miles off sat working at her window. The frame of the window was made of fine black ebony, and as she sat looking out upon the snow, she pricked her finger, and three drops of blood fell upon it. Then she gazed thoughtfully upon the red drops that sprinkled the white snow, and said, ‘Would that my little daughter may be as white as that snow, as red as that blood, and as black as this ebony windowframe!’ And so the little girl really did grow up; her skin was as white as snow, her cheeks as rosy as the blood, and her hair as black as ebony; and she was called Snowdrop.
But this queen died; and the king soon married another wife, who became queen, and was very beautiful, but so vain that she could not bear to think that anyone could be handsomer than she was. She had a fairy looking-glass, to which she used to go, and then she would gaze upon herself in it, and say:
‘Tell me, glass, tell me true!
  Of all the ladies in the land,
  Who is fairest, tell me, who?’
And the glass had always answered:
‘Thou, queen, art the fairest in all the land.’

After eating and drinking, she decides to lie down and rest.
She tries all the little beds; one is too long, another too short, until finally, the seventh bed suits her perfectly, and there she lies down and falls asleep.

events.title: The Dwarfs' Welcome and Snowdrop's New Home
detailed_summary: After some time, the occupants of the cottage, who are seven small dwarfs that search for gold in the mountains, return home.
They light their seven lamps and immediately notice that something is amiss.

The first dwarf asks who sat on his stool, the second who ate from his plate, the third who took his bread, the fourth who touched his spoon, the fifth who handled his fork, the sixth who cut with his knife, and the seventh who drank his wine.
Then, the first dwarf looks around and asks who has been lying on his bed.
The other dwarfs rush to him, each exclaiming that someone has been on their bed.
However, the seventh dwarf spots Snowdrop and calls his brothers to see her.
They exclaim in wonder and astonishment at her loveliness, bringing their lamps closer for a better look.
Pleased to see her, they take care not to disturb her sleep, and the seventh dwarf sleeps for an hour with each of the other dwarfs in turn until morning.
In the morning, Snowdrop shares her entire story with the dwarfs.
They feel sorry for her and propose that if she manages their household tasks like cooking, washing, knitting, and spinning, she can stay with them, and they will ensure her well-being.
The dwarfs then depart for their daily work of seeking gold and silver in the mountains, leaving Snowdrop at home.
Before leaving, they caution her that the queen will soon discover her whereabouts and advise her to be careful and not allow anyone into the cottage.

By and by in came the masters of the cottage. Now they were seven little dwarfs, that lived among the mountains, and dug and searched for gold. They lighted up their seven lamps, and saw at once that all was not right. The first said, ‘Who has been sitting on my stool?’ The second, ‘Who has been eating off my plate?’ The third, ‘Who has been picking my bread?’ The fourth, ‘Who has been meddling with my spoon?’ The fifth, ‘Who has been handling my fork?’ The sixth, ‘Who has been cutting with my knife?’ The seventh, ‘Who has been drinking my wine?’ Then the first looked round and said, ‘Who has been lying on my bed?’ And the rest came running to him, and everyone cried out that somebody had been upon his bed. events.title: The Queen's First Murder Attempt: The Laced Bodice
detailed_summary: The queen, under the impression that Snowdrop is dead, believes herself to be the most beautiful woman in the land and consults her mirror.
The mirror, however, reveals that the queen is the fairest in her immediate vicinity, but Snowdrop is hiding with the seven dwarfs over the hills and is far lovelier.
The queen is deeply frightened, knowing the mirror always speaks truth, and realizes her servant must have betrayed her.
Unable to bear the thought of someone more beautiful being alive, she disguises herself as an old pedlar woman and travels to the dwarfs' dwelling.
She knocks on the door, crying out that she has fine wares for sale.
Snowdrop looks out the window and inquires about the goods.
The disguised queen offers laces and bobbins of all colors.
Snowdrop, thinking the old woman seems kind, decides to let her in.
The old woman comments on how poorly Snowdrop's stays are laced and offers to lace them properly with one of her new, nice laces.
Snowdrop, suspecting no ill intent, stands before the old woman, who quickly and tightly pulls the lace, causing Snowdrop to lose her breath and fall as if dead.
The spiteful queen, believing Snowdrop's beauty finished, departs for home.
In the evening, the seven dwarfs return and are greatly grieved to find Snowdrop motionless on the ground.
They lift her, discover the constricting lace, cut it, and Snowdrop soon begins to breathe and revives.
The dwarfs then identify the old woman as the queen herself and warn Snowdrop again not to let anyone in when they are absent.

Then the miser began to beg and promise, and offered money for his liberty; but he did not come up to the musician’s price for some time, and he danced him along brisker and brisker, and the miser bid higher and higher, till at last he offered a round hundred of florins that he had in his purse, and had just gained by cheating some poor fellow. events.title: The Final Request and the Fiddle's Compulsory Dance
detailed_summary: As he stood on the steps of the gallows, the countryman made a final request to the judge.
The judge agreed to grant any request except for his life; the countryman clarified he only wished to play his fiddle one last time.
The miser vehemently protested, begging the judge not to allow it.
Despite the miser's pleas, the judge consented, stating it would be brief; this compliance was influenced by the dwarf's third gift, which compelled people to grant the countryman's requests.
Panicked, the miser cried out to be tied securely.
The countryman then took his fiddle and began to play. Instantly, the judge, clerks, and jailer started to move and caper, and no one could restrain the miser.

At the second note, the hangman released the countryman and also began dancing. By the time the first bar of the tune was played, everyone present—judge, court officials, the miser, and all the spectators—was dancing uncontrollably.
Initially, the scene was somewhat amusing, but as the music and dancing continued without end, the participants began to cry out, begging the countryman to stop.
He paid no heed to their pleas until the judge not only granted him his life but also promised the return of the hundred florins.

Then the miser said, ‘Bind me fast, bind me fast, for pity’s sake.’ But the countryman seized his fiddle, and struck up a tune, and at the first note judge, clerks, and jailer were in motion; all began capering, and no one could hold the miser. At the second note the hangman let his prisoner go, and danced also, and by the time he had played the first bar of the tune, all were dancing together—judge, court, and miser, and all the people who had followed to look on. events.title: Mother's Death, Father's Remarriage, and Ashputtel's Torment
detailed_summary: A wealthy man's wife, on her deathbed, instructed her only daughter to always be good, promising to watch over her from heaven.
Following her mother's death and burial in the garden, the little girl visited the grave daily, wept, and remained consistently good and kind.

The new wife brought her two daughters, who were fair-faced but malevolent at heart, marking the beginning of a difficult time for the little girl.
The stepsisters demeaned her, questioning her place in the parlor and asserting that she should earn her keep, ultimately calling for her to be a kitchen-maid.
They confiscated her fine clothes, gave her an old grey frock, mocked her, and confined her to the kitchen.
She was compelled to perform arduous labor: waking before dawn, carrying water, tending the fire, cooking, and washing.
Additionally, her stepsisters tormented her relentlessly and ridiculed her.
In the evenings, tired from her work, she had no bed and was forced to sleep by the hearth among the ashes, which made her perpetually dusty and dirty, leading them to call her Ashputtel.

The wife of a rich man fell sick; and when she felt that her end drew nigh, she called her only daughter to her bed-side, and said, ‘Always be a good girl, and I will look down from heaven and watch over you.’ Soon afterwards she shut her eyes and died, and was buried in the garden; and the little girl went every day to her grave and wept, and was always good and kind to all about her. And the snow fell and spread a beautiful white covering over the grave; but by the time the spring came, and the sun had melted it away again, her father had married another wife. This new wife had two daughters of her own, that she brought home with her; they were fair in face but foul at heart, and it was now a sorry time for the poor little girl. ‘What does the good-for-nothing want in the parlour?’ said they; ‘they who would eat bread should first earn it; away with the kitchen-maid!’ Then they took away her fine clothes, and gave her an old grey frock to put on, and laughed at her, and turned her into the kitchen.
There she was forced to do hard work; to rise early before daylight, to bring the water, to make the fire, to cook and to wash. Besides that, the sisters plagued her in all sorts of ways, and laughed at her. In the evening when she was tired, she had no bed to lie down on, but was made to lie by the hearth among the ashes; and as this, of course, made her always dusty and dirty, they called her Ashputtel.

events.title: A Royal Pardon, a Humble Request, and a Lifesaving Act
detailed_summary: With the ring recovered from the duck, the servant was able to convincingly demonstrate his innocence.
The king, seeking to compensate for the injustice, granted the servant permission to ask for any favor, even offering him the most prestigious position in the royal court he might desire.
The servant, however, declined all offers of courtly advancement.
Instead, he requested only a horse and some money for travel, expressing a wish to see the world and journey a little.
His modest request was granted, and he embarked on his travels.
One day, his journey led him to a pond where he observed three fish ensnared in the reeds, gasping desperately for water.
Although fish are generally considered silent, he could hear them lamenting their imminent and miserable demise.
Possessing a compassionate nature, he dismounted his horse and carefully returned the three trapped fish to the water.
The fish, filled with joy at their rescue, surfaced, put their heads out of the water, and called out to him, promising to remember his deed and repay him for saving their lives.

events.title: A Sacrifice for the Starving Ravens
detailed_summary: The side path eventually led the servant into a dense wood.
There, he witnessed a scene where two parent ravens were standing by their nest and forcibly ejecting their young ones.
The old ravens cried out to their offspring, calling them idle and worthless, stating they could no longer provide food for them and that the young birds were now large enough to fend for themselves.
The poor young ravens, however, lay on the ground, feebly flapping their wings and crying out in distress.
They lamented their helplessness, acknowledging their inability to fly and their predicament of being left to starve.
Moved by their plight, the kind young man (the servant) dismounted, drew his sword, and killed his own horse.
He then offered the horse's carcass to the starving young ravens as food.

The young ravens eagerly hopped towards the unexpected meal, ate until they were satisfied, and then cried out to him, promising to remember his sacrifice and repay his kindness, echoing the sentiment that one good turn deserves another.

events.title: Arrival in the City and the Princess's Perilous Challenge
detailed_summary: Having sacrificed his horse, the young man now had to continue his journey on foot.
After walking a considerable distance, he arrived at a large city.
The city streets were filled with a great deal of noise and a large crowd of people.
A man on horseback rode through the streets, loudly proclaiming a message: the king's daughter was seeking a husband.
However, any man who wished to marry her first had to complete a formidable task.
The announcer also warned that failure to succeed in this task would result in the forfeiture of the suitor's life.
Many men had previously attempted the challenge but had all failed, losing their lives in the process.
Despite these grim accounts, when the youth saw the king's daughter, he was so struck by her immense beauty that all thoughts of danger vanished from his mind.
He went before the king and formally declared himself as a suitor for the princess's hand.
Subsequently, he was escorted to the seashore.
In his presence, a gold ring was cast into the sea.

The king then commanded him to retrieve this ring from the ocean floor, adding a dire warning: if he resurfaced without the ring, he would be repeatedly thrown back into the sea until he drowned among the waves.
All the onlookers felt sorrow for the handsome youth as they departed, leaving him isolated by the sea.

The little kids assured their mother they would be very careful and told her she could leave without any worry.
Satisfied, the old goat bleated and left, feeling confident in her children's safety.

In front of the house there was a court, in which grew a juniper-tree. A month passed, and the snow had all disappeared; then another month went by, and all the earth was green. So the months followed one another, and first the trees budded in the woods, and soon the green branches grew thickly intertwined, and then the blossoms began to fall. Once again the wife stood under the juniper-tree, and it was so full of sweet scent that her heart leaped for joy, and she was so overcome with her happiness, that she fell on her knees. Presently the fruit became round and firm, and she was glad and at peace; but when they were fully ripe she picked the berries and ate eagerly of them, and then she grew sad and ill. A little while later she called her husband, and said to him, weeping. ‘If I die, bury me under the juniper-tree.’ Then she felt comforted and happy again, and before another month had passed she had a little child, and when she saw that it was as white as snow and as red as blood, her joy was so great that she died.

events.title: The Boy's Transformation into a Bird at the Juniper Tree
detailed_summary: Little Marleen went to her room, took her finest silk handkerchief from her drawer, and used it to gather all the bones from under the table, weeping all the while.
She carried them outside and laid them in the green grass beneath the juniper tree.
As soon as she had done this, her sadness seemed to lift, and she stopped weeping.
The juniper tree then began to stir, its branches moving back and forth, apart and then together, as if joyfully clapping.
A mist enveloped the tree, and within the mist, a fire-like burning appeared.
Out of this fire, a beautiful bird emerged, soaring high into the air, singing magnificently.
When the bird was no longer visible, the juniper tree stood as it was before, and both the silk handkerchief and the bones had vanished.
Little Marleen then felt as lighthearted and happy as if her brother were still alive.
She returned to the house, sat down cheerfully at the table, and ate.

He found the song so beautiful that he got up and ran outside, losing one of his slippers in his haste.

He continued into the middle of the street, with one slipper on and a sock on the other foot, still wearing his apron and holding the gold chain and pincers, and stood there gazing up at the bird as the sun shone brightly.
The goldsmith addressed the bird, praising its beautiful singing and requesting it to sing the song again.
The bird replied that it does not sing twice for nothing and asked for the gold chain in return.
The goldsmith readily agreed, offering the chain and urging the bird to sing again.
The bird flew down, took the gold chain in its right claw, then returned to its perch before the goldsmith and sang its song once more.
