detailed_summary: Upon finishing its song, the bird spread its wings and, carrying the gold chain in its right claw, the shoes in its left, and the millstone around its neck, flew directly to its father's house.
Inside, the father, the mother, and little Marleen were having dinner.
The father remarked on how lighthearted, pleased, and cheerful he felt.
In contrast, the mother expressed feeling very uneasy, as if a heavy thunderstorm were approaching.
Little Marleen sat weeping continuously.
The bird then flew towards the house and settled on the roof.
The father's happiness increased, noting the beautiful sunshine and feeling as if he were about to see an old friend.
The wife, however, felt immense distress and uneasiness, her teeth chattering, and a sensation like fire in her veins; she tore open her dress in agitation.
All this time, Marleen sat in a corner weeping, her tears wetting the plate on her knees.
The bird then flew to the juniper tree and began to sing its song about its mother killing it.
The mother shut her eyes and ears to block out the sight and sound, but experienced a roaring in her ears like a violent storm and a burning, flashing sensation in her eyes like lightning.
As the bird sang of its father's grief, the father commented to the mother about the beautiful bird singing magnificently, the warm sun, and the delicious scent of spice in the air.
When the bird sang of its sister's love, little Marleen laid her head on her knees and sobbed.
The father decided to go outside to see the bird more closely.
The wife frantically cried out for him not to go, feeling as if the whole house were in flames.
But the man went out and looked at the bird as it sang about the sister laying a kerchief over it and placing its bones under the juniper tree, ending with its refrain.
With that, the bird let the gold chain fall, and it landed perfectly around the man's neck.
He went back inside, showing the beautiful gold chain the splendid bird had given him and remarking on the bird's beauty.
The wife, overcome with fear and trouble, fell to the floor, her cap falling from her head.
The bird began to sing again about its mother killing it.
The wife cried out, wishing she were a thousand feet beneath the earth to escape the song.
As the bird sang of its father's grief, the woman fell down again as if dead.
When the bird sang of its sister's love, little Marleen decided to go out too, to see if the bird would give her anything.
As she went out, the bird sang of the sister's actions and threw down the red shoes to her.
Marleen instantly felt happy and lighthearted; she put on the shoes and danced and jumped in them, remarking how her earlier misery had vanished and praising the splendid bird for the gift.

And when he had finished his song, he spread his wings, and with the chain in his right claw, the shoes in his left, and the millstone round his neck, he flew right away to his father’s house.
The father, the mother, and little Marleen were having their dinner.
‘How lighthearted I feel,’ said the father, ‘so pleased and cheerful.’
‘And I,’ said the mother, ‘I feel so uneasy, as if a heavy thunderstorm were coming.’
But little Marleen sat and wept and wept.
Then the bird came flying towards the house and settled on the roof.
‘I do feel so happy,’ said the father, ‘and how beautifully the sun shines; I feel just as if I were going to see an old friend again.’
‘Ah!’ said the wife, ‘and I am so full of distress and uneasiness that my teeth chatter, and I feel as if there were a fire in my veins,’ and she tore open her dress; and all the while little Marleen sat in the corner and wept, and the plate on her knees was wet with her tears.
The bird now flew to the juniper-tree and began singing:
‘My mother killed her little son;
the mother shut her eyes and her ears, that she might see and hear nothing, but there was a roaring sound in her ears like that of a violent storm, and in her eyes a burning and flashing like lightning:
My father grieved when I was gone;
‘Look, mother,’ said the man, ‘at the beautiful bird that is singing so magnificently; and how warm and bright the sun is, and what a delicious scent of spice in the air!’
My sister loved me best of all;
then little Marleen laid her head down on her knees and sobbed.
‘I must go outside and see the bird nearer,’ said the man.
‘Ah, do not go!’ cried the wife. ‘I feel as if the whole house were in flames!’
But the man went out and looked at the bird.
She laid her kerchief over me,
 And took my bones that they might lie
 Underneath the juniper-tree
 Kywitt, Kywitt, what a beautiful bird am I!’
With that the bird let fall the gold chain, and it fell just round the man’s neck, so that it fitted him exactly.
He went inside, and said, ‘See, what a splendid bird that is; he has given me this beautiful gold chain, and looks so beautiful himself.’
But the wife was in such fear and trouble, that she fell on the floor, and her cap fell from her head.
Then the bird began again:
‘My mother killed her little son;
‘Ah me!’ cried the wife, ‘if I were but a thousand feet beneath the earth, that I might not hear that song.’
My father grieved when I was gone;
then the woman fell down again as if dead.
My sister loved me best of all;
‘Well,’ said little Marleen, ‘I will go out too and see if the bird will give me anything.’
So she went out.
She laid her kerchief over me,
  And took my bones that they might lie
and he threw down the shoes to her,
Underneath the juniper-tree
  Kywitt, Kywitt, what a beautiful bird am I!’
And she now felt quite happy and lighthearted; she put on the shoes and danced and jumped about in them. ‘I was so miserable,’ she said, ‘when I came out, but that has all passed away; that is indeed a splendid bird, and he has given me a pair of red shoes.’

events.title: The Humble Gardener and the King's Generosity

events.text_segment:
There were two brothers who were both soldiers; the one was rich and the other poor. The poor man thought he would try to better himself; so, pulling off his red coat, he became a gardener, and dug his ground well, and sowed turnips.
When the seed came up, there was one plant bigger than all the rest; and it kept getting larger and larger, and seemed as if it would never cease growing; so that it might have been called the prince of turnips for there never was such a one seen before, and never will again. At last it was so big that it filled a cart, and two oxen could hardly draw it; and the gardener knew not what in the world to do with it, nor whether it would be a blessing or a curse to him. One day he said to himself, ‘What shall I do with it? if I sell it, it will bring no more than another; and for eating, the little turnips are better than this; the best thing perhaps is to carry it and give it to the king as a mark of respect.’
Then he yoked his oxen, and drew the turnip to the court, and gave it to the king. ‘What a wonderful thing!’ said the king; ‘I have seen many strange things, but such a monster as this I never saw. Where did you get the seed? or is it only your good luck? If so, you are a true child of fortune.’ ‘Ah, no!’ answered the gardener, ‘I am no child of fortune; I am a poor soldier, who never could get enough to live upon; so I laid aside my red coat, and set to work, tilling the ground. I have a brother, who is rich, and your majesty knows him well, and all the world knows him; but because I am poor, everybody forgets me.’
The king then took pity on him, and said, ‘You shall be poor no longer. I will give you so much that you shall be even richer than your brother.’ Then he gave him gold and lands and flocks, and made him so rich that his brother’s fortune could not at all be compared with his.

events.title: Gretel Accompanies Hans and is Tied to a Rack
detailed_summary: Hans departs for Gretel's home yet again, after the now well-established exchange with his mother.
He greets Gretel and repeats his wish to be given something.
To Hans's surprise, Gretel announces that she will accompany him back to his home.
Interpreting his mother's advice about leading animals with a rope, Hans takes Gretel, ties her with a rope, leads her to the animal feeding rack, and secures her there.
He then goes to his mother and reports on his visit to Gretel's.
He clarifies that Gretel did not give him a tangible gift but instead came with him.
When his mother asks where Gretel is, Hans details how he treated her like livestock: leading her by a rope, tying her to the rack, and even scattering some grass for her.
His mother, appalled, tells him his behavior was wrong and that he should have cast friendly eyes upon Gretel.
Hans responds with a promise to 'do better,' notably omitting 'next time.'

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
**"Whither away, Hans?"**  

Hans stopped in his tracks, his sack slung over his shoulder, and turned to see his old friend Peter leaning against the fence, grinning. The morning sun cast long shadows across the dusty road, and the scent of fresh bread from the village bakery lingered in the air.  

"Ah, Peter!" Hans replied, wiping his brow with the back of his hand. "I’m off to seek my fortune. The world is wide, and I’ve heard there’s work to be had in the next town over."  

Peter chuckled, shaking his head. "Always the dreamer, Hans. But what have you got in that sack of yours? Surely not another foolish trade?"  

Hans grinned sheepishly. "Well… I may have swapped my cow for a handful of magic beans."  

Peter groaned. "Not again! You never learn, do you?"  

But Hans only laughed, his eyes twinkling with mischief. "Ah, but you never know, Peter! These might be the beans that change my luck!"  

And with that, he tipped his hat and continued down the road, whistling a merry tune.  

### **The Journey Begins**  

Hans had always been a simple soul, content with little and ever hopeful for more. His mother often scolded him for his foolish bargains—trading their last loaf of bread for a rusty old lantern, or giving away his only pair of shoes for a song. But Hans never minded. "Fortune favors the bold!" he would say, and off he’d go again.  

This time, however, something felt different. The beans in his sack seemed to hum with a strange energy, and as he walked, the road stretched longer than he remembered. The trees whispered secrets, and the wind carried laughter from unseen lips.  

By nightfall, Hans found himself deep in the woods, far from any village. The moon hung heavy in the sky, casting eerie silver light upon the path. Just as he was about to lay down his sack and rest, a soft glow caught his eye.  

There, nestled between the roots of an ancient oak, was a tiny door.  

### **The Little Door**  

Hans crouched down, curiosity burning in his chest. The door was no bigger than his hand, carved with intricate patterns of vines and stars. He reached out, half-expecting it to vanish like a dream, but his fingers brushed solid wood.  

"Now what do we have here?" he murmured.  

Then, before he could think better of it, he knocked.  

The door creaked open, revealing a passage just large enough for him to crawl through. Without hesitation, Hans pushed his sack ahead and squeezed inside.  

The tunnel twisted and turned, leading him deeper underground. The air grew warm and sweet, like honey and cinnamon. At last, he emerged into a vast cavern, lit by thousands of flickering fireflies.  

And there, in the center of it all, stood a table piled high with gold and jewels.  

### **The Guardian of the Treasure**  

Hans gasped, his heart pounding. He had heard tales of hidden hoards guarded by dragons or trolls, but the cavern was silent.  

Then, a voice like rustling leaves spoke behind him.  

"Who dares enter the realm of the Gnome King?"  

Hans whirled around to see a tiny figure no taller than his knee. The gnome had a long white beard, a pointed hat, and eyes that gleamed like polished coal.  

"Forgive me, good sir!" Hans stammered, bowing low. "I meant no trespass. I only followed the door."  

The gnome studied him, stroking his beard. "Hmm. Most who find my door are greedy or cruel. But you… you are different."  

Hans blinked. "I am?"  

The gnome nodded. "You seek fortune, yet you do not grasp for it with greedy hands. You are foolish, but your heart is light."  

Hans grinned. "That’s what my mother always says!"  

The gnome chuckled. "Very well. For your honesty, I shall grant you a gift. But choose wisely—for not all that glitters is gold."  

### **The Choice**  

Hans looked at the treasure, then at the gnome. "If I may ask… what is the greatest treasure here?"  

The gnome’s eyes twinkled. "Ah! A wise question. The greatest treasure is not the gold, nor the jewels, but the magic that lies within." He gestured to three small chests at the edge of the table.  

"The first holds endless wealth," the gnome said. "The second, boundless knowledge. The third… the power to bring joy to others."  

Hans scratched his head. "Well, I’ve never been one for books, and gold never stays in my pockets long. But making others happy… that sounds like a fine thing indeed."  

The gnome smiled. "Then your choice is made."  

### **The Return**  

When Hans crawled back through the tunnel, he found himself at the edge of his own village. The sun was just rising, painting the sky in hues of pink and gold.  

Peter was still at the fence, yawning. "Hans? Where have you been all night?"  

Hans grinned, holding up a small wooden flute—the only thing he had taken from the gnome’s treasure. "You’ll never believe it, Peter!"  

And as he played, the music filled the air, and for the first time in years, the villagers laughed and danced without a care in the world.  

For Hans had found the greatest treasure of all—the gift of joy.  

And so, dear reader, remember: sometimes the simplest hearts find the richest fortunes.  

**The End.**

events.title: Hans's Final Cruelty and Gretel's Escape

He commits a gruesome act by cutting out the eyes of all the calves and sheep he finds there.
He then returns to Gretel and throws these dismembered eyes in her face.
This cruel and shocking action deeply angers Gretel.
Filled with rage, Gretel manages to break free from the ropes binding her.
She immediately flees from Hans and his home, thereby definitively ending any possibility of her becoming his bride.

events.title: The Unconventional Student and a Father's Disownment
detailed_summary: An elderly count in Switzerland had a son who was perceived as unintelligent and incapable of learning.
The father, frustrated by his inability to educate his son, decided to send him to a renowned master for instruction.
After a year with the first master, the son returned home, having only learned to understand the barking of dogs.
The count, dismayed by this singular, unconventional skill, sent his son to a different master in another town.
Following another year of study, the son came back, this time reporting that he had learned to understand what birds say.
The father became extremely angry, berating his son for wasting time and learning nothing of practical value, and threatened to disown him if he failed with a third master.
The youth spent a year with a third master and returned, stating he had learned what frogs croak.
Overcome with fury, the father declared the youth was no longer his son, ordered his servants to take him into the forest, and kill him.
The servants, feeling pity for the youth, could not bring themselves to kill him and instead let him go, deceiving the count by presenting parts from a deer as proof of his death.

events.title: The Youth, the Bewitched Dogs, and the Hidden Treasure
detailed_summary: The exiled youth, wandering, arrived at a fortress and requested shelter for the night.
The lord of the castle permitted him to stay in an old tower but warned him that it was perilous, as it was filled with savage dogs that barked incessantly and periodically devoured a human victim.
The entire region was distressed by these dogs, but no solution had been found.
The youth, showing no fear, asked to be allowed into the tower with some food to pacify the dogs, confident they would not injure him.
Given food for the animals, he was led to the tower.
Upon entering, the dogs did not bark at him but instead wagged their tails in a friendly manner, ate the food he offered, and left him completely unharmed.
The next morning, he emerged safely, much to everyone's surprise, and explained to the castle's lord that the dogs had communicated to him their plight.
He revealed that the dogs were cursed to guard a large treasure hidden in the tower and could not find peace until it was removed, also stating he learned from them how to accomplish this.
Those who heard this were overjoyed, and the lord promised to adopt the youth as his son if he successfully retrieved the treasure.
The youth descended into the tower again, performed the necessary actions as he understood them, and brought out a chest filled with gold.
Consequently, the howling of the wild dogs ceased, they vanished, and the land was relieved of its affliction.

The youth, however, was without fear, and said: ‘Just let me go down to the barking dogs, and give me something that I can throw to them; they will do nothing to harm me.’ As he himself would have it so, they gave him some food for the wild animals, and led him down to the tower. When he went inside, the dogs did not bark at him, but wagged their tails quite amicably around him, ate what he set before them, and did not hurt one hair of his head. Next morning, to the astonishment of everyone, he came out again safe and unharmed, and said to the lord of the castle: ‘The dogs have revealed to me, in their own language, why they dwell there, and bring evil on the land. They are bewitched, and are obliged to watch over a great treasure which is below in the tower, and they can have no rest until it is taken away, and I have likewise learnt, from their discourse, how that is to be done.’ Then all who heard this rejoiced, and the lord of the castle said he would adopt him as a son if he accomplished it successfully. He went down again, and as he knew what he had to do, he did it thoroughly, and brought a chest full of gold out with him. The howling of the wild dogs was henceforth heard no more; they had disappeared, and the country was freed from the trouble.

events.title: The Princess's Rescue, a Royal Dispute, and a Generous Reward
detailed_summary: Upon bringing the princess back to her father, there was widespread rejoicing.

The huntsman asserted she was his because if he hadn't killed the dragon, it would have destroyed them all.
The tailor argued that if he hadn't repaired the boat, they all would have drowned, making her his by right.
The king intervened, acknowledging the validity of each claim.
He reasoned that since all four could not marry the princess, and because she was actually fond of someone else, it was best if none of them married her.
To compensate for their efforts and loss, he offered to give each of them half a kingdom as a reward for their skill.
The brothers agreed this resolution was preferable to continued quarreling or marrying an unwilling bride.
The king fulfilled his promise, granting each half a kingdom, and they lived contentedly, also taking care of their father, while the princess was ensured to be safe from future harm.

And when the time came for him to go home, he had bought pearls and jewels for the two eldest, but he had sought everywhere in vain for the rose; and when he went into any garden and asked for such a thing, the people laughed at him, and asked him whether he thought roses grew in snow. This grieved him very much, for Lily was his dearest child; and as he was journeying home, thinking what he should bring her, he came to a fine castle; and around the castle was a garden, in one half of which it seemed to be summer-time and in the other half winter. On one side the finest flowers were in full bloom, and on the other everything looked dreary and buried in the snow. ‘A lucky hit!’ said he, as he called to his servant, and told him to go to a beautiful bed of roses that was there, and bring him away one of the finest flowers.

detailed_summary: Upon securing the rose and attempting to leave, the merchant and his servant were suddenly confronted by a fierce lion.

This done, they were riding away well pleased, when up sprang a fierce lion, and roared out, ‘Whoever has stolen my roses shall be eaten up alive!’ Then the man said, ‘I knew not that the garden belonged to you; can nothing save my life?’ ‘No!’ said the lion, ‘nothing, unless you undertake to give me whatever meets you on your return home; if you agree to this, I will give you your life, and the rose too for your daughter.’ But the man was unwilling to do so and said, ‘It may be my youngest daughter, who loves me most, and always runs to meet me when I go home.’ Then the servant was greatly frightened, and said, ‘It may perhaps be only a cat or a dog.’ And at last the man yielded with a heavy heart, and took the rose; and said he would give the lion whatever should meet him first on his return.
And as he came near home, it was Lily, his youngest and dearest daughter, that met him; she came running, and kissed him, and welcomed him home; and when she saw that he had brought her the rose, she was still more glad. But her father began to be very sorrowful, and to weep, saying, ‘Alas, my dearest child! I have bought this flower at a high price, for I have said I would give you to a wild lion; and when he has you, he will tear you in pieces, and eat you.’ Then he told her all that had happened, and said she should not go, let what would happen.
But she comforted him, and said, ‘Dear father, the word you have given must be kept; I will go to the lion, and soothe him: perhaps he will let me come safe home again.’
The next morning she asked the way she was to go, and took leave of her father, and went forth with a bold heart into the wood.

events.title: Lily's Seven-Year Ordeal and Celestial Assistance
detailed_summary: Following his statement, the prince, now a dove, flew out the door, and poor Lily began her pursuit, guided intermittently by a falling white feather that indicated her route.
In this manner, she roamed continuously through the vast world, never looking aside or taking any rest for a period of seven years.
As the seven-year mark approached, she started to feel glad, believing her troubles were nearing an end; yet, relief was still distant.
One day, while traveling, she realized she had missed the white feather, and upon looking up, she could no longer see the dove anywhere.
She thought to herself that no human assistance could now be of use to her.
So, she approached the Sun, explaining its universal reach, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Sun replied that it had not seen the dove but offered her a casket, instructing her to open it when her hour of need arrived.
Lily thanked the Sun and continued her journey until evening.
When the Moon rose, she cried out to it, describing its nightly illumination, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Moon responded that it could not help her but would give her an egg, advising her to break it when the need arose.
She thanked the Moon and journeyed on until the night-wind began to blow.
She addressed the Night-Wind, noting its pervasive presence, and asked if it had seen her white dove.
The Night-Wind replied that it had not but would consult three other winds.
The East Wind and West Wind subsequently reported they had not seen the dove either.
However, the South Wind stated it had seen the white dove, revealing he had flown to the Red Sea and transformed back into a lion, as the seven years had passed.
The South Wind added that the lion was currently fighting a dragon, which was an enchanted princess attempting to separate him from Lily.
The Night-Wind then offered counsel: Lily should go to the Red Sea, where on the right shore she would find many rods. She was to count them, break off the eleventh, and strike the dragon with it.
This act would grant the lion victory, and both he and the dragon would revert to their true forms.
Afterward, she should look for a griffin by the Red Sea, jump onto its back with her beloved as quickly as possible, and it would transport them across the waters to their home.

The Night-Wind also gave her a nut, instructing her to throw it down when they were halfway across the sea. This would cause a tall nut-tree to spring from the waters, allowing the griffin to rest, as it would otherwise lack the strength for the entire journey; forgetting this would result in them both falling into the sea.

Thus she went roving on through the wide world, and looked neither to the right hand nor to the left, nor took any rest, for seven years. Then she began to be glad, and thought to herself that the time was fast coming when all her troubles should end; yet repose was still far off, for one day as she was travelling on she missed the white feather, and when she lifted up her eyes she could nowhere see the dove. ‘Now,’ thought she to herself, ‘no aid of man can be of use to me.’ So she went to the sun and said, ‘Thou shinest everywhere, on the hill’s top and the valley’s depth—hast thou anywhere seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the sun, ‘I have not seen it; but I will give thee a casket—open it when thy hour of need comes.’
So she thanked the sun, and went on her way till eventide; and when the moon arose, she cried unto it, and said, ‘Thou shinest through the night, over field and grove—hast thou nowhere seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the moon, ‘I cannot help thee but I will give thee an egg—break it when need comes.’
Then she thanked the moon, and went on till the night-wind blew; and she raised up her voice to it, and said, ‘Thou blowest through every tree and under every leaf—hast thou not seen my white dove?’ ‘No,’ said the night-wind, ‘but I will ask three other winds; perhaps they have seen it.’ Then the east wind and the west wind came, and said they too had not seen it, but the south wind said, ‘I have seen the white dove—he has fled to the Red Sea, and is changed once more into a lion, for the seven years are passed away, and there he is fighting with a dragon; and the dragon is an enchanted princess, who seeks to separate him from you.’ Then the night-wind said, ‘I will give thee counsel. Go to the Red Sea; on the right shore stand many rods—count them, and when thou comest to the eleventh, break it off, and smite the dragon with it; and so the lion will have the victory, and both of them will appear to you in their own forms. Then look round and thou wilt see a griffin, winged like bird, sitting by the Red Sea; jump on to his back with thy beloved one as quickly as possible, and he will carry you over the waters to your home. I will also give thee this nut,’ continued the night-wind. ‘When you are half-way over, throw it down, and out of the waters will immediately spring up a high nut-tree on which the griffin will be able to rest, otherwise he would not have the strength to bear you the whole way; if, therefore, thou dost forget to throw down the nut, he will let you both fall into the sea.’

This said, he flew out at the door, and poor Lily followed; and every now and then a white feather fell, and showed her the way she was to journey.  

The path was long and winding, leading her through dark forests where the trees whispered secrets in the wind, across rushing rivers where the water sang eerie melodies, and over hills that seemed to stretch endlessly into the mist. Yet, wherever she went, the white feathers gleamed like little stars against the earth, guiding her onward.  

Lily’s heart was heavy with sorrow, for she did not know where the bird was leading her, nor what fate awaited her at the end of this strange journey. But she dared not turn back, for she had no home to return to—only the memory of a cottage now empty, a hearth now cold.  

At last, as the sun dipped below the horizon and the sky turned the color of bruised violets, she came upon a clearing in the woods. There, standing in the center, was a great silver tree, its branches shimmering as though woven from moonlight. And perched upon the highest bough was the white bird, watching her with eyes like polished gems.  

"Welcome, Lily," the bird said, its voice soft as a sigh. "You have followed faithfully, and now you shall be rewarded."  

Before she could speak, the tree began to tremble, and from its trunk stepped a woman clad in robes of woven starlight. Her face was kind, yet ancient, and her eyes held the wisdom of centuries.  

"Long have I waited for one pure of heart to find this place," the woman said. "You, dear child, have suffered much, but your kindness has not gone unseen."  

Lily fell to her knees, tears streaming down her cheeks. "Who are you?" she whispered.  

"I am the Guardian of the Lost," the woman replied. "And this tree is the heart of all forgotten things—love, hope, and dreams abandoned by the world. But you, Lily, have not forgotten. You have kept faith when others would have turned away."  

With a wave of her hand, the woman beckoned the white bird, which fluttered down and landed upon Lily’s shoulder. "This bird is no ordinary creature," she explained. "It is the spirit of your mother, who has watched over you all this time."  

Lily gasped, her heart swelling with both joy and sorrow. "Mother?"  

The bird nuzzled her cheek, and in that moment, Lily felt a warmth she had not known since her mother’s passing.  

"Now," said the Guardian, "you must choose. You may stay here, where sorrow cannot touch you, or return to the world and carry this light within you, to guide others as you have been guided."  

Lily hesitated only a moment before lifting her chin. "I will go back," she said firmly. "For if there are others lost as I was, I would help them find their way."  

The Guardian smiled, and with a final whisper of wind, the silver tree faded, the clearing vanished, and Lily found herself standing once more at the edge of the forest, the first light of dawn breaking over the trees.  

And though the white bird was gone, she knew she would never truly be alone again.

events.title: Magical Gifts, Deception, and the Prince's Miraculous Awakening
detailed_summary: Lily, invoking heavenly aid, took the casket given to her by the Sun and discovered within it a dress as radiant as the sun itself.
She put on the dress and entered the palace, where all the people gazed at her in admiration.
The dazzling dress greatly pleased the bride (the princess), who inquired if it was for sale.
Lily replied that it was not available for gold and silver, but rather for 'flesh and blood'.
When the princess asked for clarification, Lily requested permission to speak with the bridegroom in his chamber that night, offering the dress in exchange.
The princess eventually consented but secretly instructed her chamberlain to administer a sleeping draught to the prince to ensure he would neither hear nor see Lily.
When evening arrived and the prince had fallen asleep, Lily was escorted into his chamber.

She sat at his feet and spoke of her seven-year pursuit, her consultations with the sun, moon, and night-wind, and her role in helping him defeat the dragon, questioning if he would then completely forget her.
However, the prince remained so soundly asleep that her voice merely passed over him, resembling the sound of wind whistling through fir-trees.
Poor Lily was then led away and compelled to surrender the golden dress.
Realizing there was no immediate help for her, she went into a meadow, sat down, and wept.
While seated there, she remembered the egg given to her by the Moon.
Upon breaking it, a hen and twelve chickens made of pure gold emerged, played about, and then nestled under the hen's wings, creating a most beautiful spectacle.
She rose and guided them before her until the bride saw them from her window.
The sight so pleased the princess that she came out and asked Lily if she would sell the brood.
Lily responded with the same terms: 'Not for gold or silver, but for flesh and blood: let me again this evening speak with the bridegroom in his chamber, and I will give thee the whole brood.'
The princess, intending to deceive Lily as before, agreed to her request.
However, when the prince retired to his chamber, he asked the chamberlain why the wind had whistled so strangely during the night.

The chamberlain then revealed everything: how he had administered a sleeping draught to the prince, how a poor maiden had come and spoken to him in his chamber, and that she was scheduled to return again that night.
Consequently, the prince made sure to discard the sleeping draught.
When Lily arrived and began once more to recount the sorrows that had befallen her and how faithful and true she had remained to him, he recognized the voice of his beloved wife.

He sprang up, exclaiming that she had awakened him as if from a dream, explaining that the strange princess had cast a spell upon him, causing him to forget her entirely, but that Heaven had providentially sent Lily to him at a fortunate moment.

events.text_segment: There was once upon a time a soldier who for many years had served the king faithfully, but when the war came to an end could serve no longer because of the many wounds which he had received. The king said to him: ‘You may return to your home, I need you no longer, and you will not receive any more money, for he only receives wages who renders me service for them.’ Then the soldier did not know how to earn a living, went away greatly troubled, and walked the whole day, until in the evening he entered a forest. When darkness came on, he saw a light, which he went up to, and came to a house wherein lived a witch. ‘Do give me one night’s lodging, and a little to eat and drink,’ said he to her, ‘or I shall starve.’ ‘Oho!’ she answered, ‘who gives anything to a run-away soldier? Yet will I be compassionate, and take you in, if you will do what I wish.’ ‘What do you wish?’ said the soldier. ‘That you should dig all round my garden for me, tomorrow.’ The soldier consented, and next day laboured with all his strength, but could not finish it by the evening. ‘I see well enough,’ said the witch, ‘that you can do no more today, but I will keep you yet another night, in payment for which you must tomorrow chop me a load of wood, and chop it small.’ The soldier spent the whole day in doing it, and in the evening the witch proposed that he should stay one night more. ‘Tomorrow, you shall only do me a very trifling piece of work. Behind my house, there is an old dry well, into which my light has fallen, it burns blue, and never goes out, and you shall bring it up again.’ Next day the old woman took him to the well, and let him down in a basket. He found the blue light, and made her a signal to draw him up again. She did draw him up, but when he came near the edge, she stretched down her hand and wanted to take the blue light away from him. ‘No,’ said he, perceiving her evil intention, ‘I will not give you the light until I am standing with both feet upon the ground.’ The witch fell into a passion, let him fall again into the well, and went away.

He commanded the manikin to bring the king's daughter to him in her sleep, to perform servant's work.

events.title: The Soldier's Final Plea, The Manikin's Intervention, and Ultimate Triumph
detailed_summary: Chained in his dungeon, the soldier saw a former comrade pass by his window.
He tapped on the glass, and when the man approached, the soldier asked him to fetch a small bundle he had left at the inn, offering a ducat for this service.
His comrade retrieved the bundle and brought it to him.
Once alone, the soldier lit his pipe with the blue light, summoning the black manikin.
The manikin told his master not to fear, to go wherever they took him, and to ensure he had the blue light with him.
The next day, the soldier was tried and, despite having done nothing wicked in the conventional sense, was condemned to death by the judge.
As he was led to his execution, he begged a last favor from the king: to be allowed to smoke one more pipe on his way.
The king granted him permission to smoke three pipes but stated this would not spare his life.
The soldier pulled out his pipe, lit it at the blue light, and as smoke wreaths ascended, the manikin appeared with a small cudgel, asking for commands.
The soldier ordered him to strike down the false judge, his constable, and not to spare the king who had treated him so poorly.
The manikin attacked like lightning, felling anyone touched by his cudgel, rendering them unable to move.
Terrified, the king threw himself on the soldier's mercy and, to be allowed to live, gave the soldier his kingdom and his daughter in marriage.

The old woman, who was far wiser than she appeared, studied him closely. "And what sorrow could be so great that it steals your appetite?" she asked, stirring a pot of soup over the fire.

The old woman nodded in satisfaction. "Good. Now, tell me your story. For every tale, no matter how sad, must be spoken before it can be healed."  

And so, as the fire crackled and the scent of herbs filled the air, the young man began to speak.

events.title: The Man's Renewed Quest and Encounter with a Hungry Giant
detailed_summary: Upon awakening and realizing he had slept through the princess's visit yet again, the man was deeply distressed, lamenting that she had likely departed and that his chance to save her was lost.
His attention was then drawn to the items lying beside him; he read the letter and fully understood the events that had transpired.
He rose immediately, eager to begin his journey to the castle of Stromberg, though he was entirely unsure of which direction to take.
He wandered for a considerable time in search of it and eventually found himself in a dark forest, through which he walked for fourteen days without discovering an exit.
As night fell once more, exhausted, he lay down beneath a bush and fell asleep.
The next day he continued his journey through the forest, and that evening, intending to rest, he lay down again but was kept awake by terrifying howling and wailing sounds.
He waited until the surroundings grew darker and people began to illuminate their homes, then noticed a faint glimmer of light in the distance and moved towards it.
He discovered the light emanated from a house that seemed smaller than its actual size due to the presence of an enormous giant standing before it.
The man initially feared for his life, thinking the giant would surely harm him if seen, but eventually mustered his courage and approached.
When the giant spotted him, he declared the man's arrival opportune, as he hadn't eaten for a long time and planned to make the man his supper.
The man protested, stating he did not wish to be eaten and offered to satisfy the giant's hunger with the ample provisions he carried.
The giant, upon hearing this offer, agreed to spare him, explaining his intention to eat the man stemmed only from a lack of alternative food.

When the man awoke and found that he had been sleeping, he was grieved at heart, and said, ‘She has no doubt been here and driven away again, and it is now too late for me to save her.’ Then his eyes fell on the things which were lying beside him; he read the letter, and knew from it all that had happened. He rose up without delay, eager to start on his way and to reach the castle of Stromberg, but he had no idea in which direction he ought to go. He travelled about a long time in search of it and came at last to a dark forest, through which he went on walking for fourteen days and still could not find a way out. Once more the night came on, and worn out he lay down under a bush and fell asleep. Again the next day he pursued his way through the forest, and that evening, thinking to rest again, he lay down as before, but he heard such a howling and wailing that he found it impossible to sleep. He waited till it was darker and people had begun to light up their houses, and then seeing a little glimmer ahead of him, he went towards it.
He found that the light came from a house which looked smaller than it really was, from the contrast of its height with that of an immense giant who stood in front of it. He thought to himself, ‘If the giant sees me going in, my life will not be worth much.’ However, after a while he summoned up courage and went forward. When the giant saw him, he called out, ‘It is lucky for that you have come, for I have not had anything to eat for a long time. I can have you now for my supper.’ ‘I would rather you let that alone,’ said the man, ‘for I do not willingly give myself up to be eaten; if you are wanting food I have enough to satisfy your hunger.’ ‘If that is so,’ replied the giant, ‘I will leave you in peace; I only thought of eating you because I had nothing else.’

*‘Come with me,’* the woodcutter said, leading them into the forest. After a long walk, they reached a clearing where a great oak stood. Beneath its roots, the old man dug until he uncovered a chest. When he opened it, instead of gold, they found only a simple book.  

*‘This is the treasure,’* the woodcutter said. *‘It is the word of God, and it teaches kindness, mercy, and brotherhood.’*  

The robbers scoffed at first, but as the woodcutter read to them, their hearts softened. They left their life of crime, and from that day on, they lived as honest men, helping others as the woodcutter had helped them.  

And so, the old man’s simple greeting—*‘God be with you’*—had changed their lives forever.

events.title: The Elder Brothers' Selfishness and Misfortune
detailed_summary: The narrative introduces a man with three sons, the youngest named Dummling, who is consistently looked down upon.
The eldest son prepared to go into the forest to cut wood, equipped by his mother with a fine cake and wine to prevent hunger and thirst.
In the forest, he encountered a small, elderly grey-haired man who asked for some food and drink due to his own hunger and thirst.
The eldest son, described as clever, selfishly refused, stating he would have none left for himself, and continued on his way, leaving the old man.

While attempting to chop down a tree, the eldest son quickly made an errant swing with his axe, injuring his arm and forcing him to return home for medical attention. This misfortune was attributed to the little grey man's influence.
Subsequently, the second son ventured into the forest, similarly provisioned by his mother with cake and wine.
He too met the little old grey man, who made the same request for a piece of cake and a drink of wine.
The second son also rationally declined, reasoning that sharing would leave him with nothing, and went on, leaving the old man.
His retribution followed swiftly; after a few swings at a tree, he struck his own leg and had to be transported back home.

There was a man who had three sons, the youngest of whom was called Dummling,[*] and was despised, mocked, and sneered at on every occasion.
It happened that the eldest wanted to go into the forest to hew wood, and before he went his mother gave him a beautiful sweet cake and a bottle of wine in order that he might not suffer from hunger or thirst.
When he entered the forest he met a little grey-haired old man who bade him good day, and said: ‘Do give me a piece of cake out of your pocket, and let me have a draught of your wine; I am so hungry and thirsty.’ But the clever son answered: ‘If I give you my cake and wine, I shall have none for myself; be off with you,’ and he left the little man standing and went on.
But when he began to hew down a tree, it was not long before he made a false stroke, and the axe cut him in the arm, so that he had to go home and have it bound up. And this was the little grey man’s doing.
After this the second son went into the forest, and his mother gave him, like the eldest, a cake and a bottle of wine. The little old grey man met him likewise, and asked him for a piece of cake and a drink of wine. But the second son, too, said sensibly enough: ‘What I give you will be taken away from myself; be off!’ and he left the little man standing and went on. His punishment, however, was not delayed; when he had made a few blows at the tree he struck himself in the leg, so that he had to be carried home.

events.title: Making the Princess Laugh and the First Royal Task Initiated
detailed_summary: Shortly thereafter, Dummling arrived in a city ruled by a king whose daughter was so perpetually serious that no one could make her laugh.
The king had issued a decree stating that whoever could make his daughter laugh would be permitted to marry her.
When Dummling learned of this, he went with his goose and its entire train of seven followers before the king's daughter.
As soon as the princess saw the seven people continuously running one behind the other, she began to laugh uproariously, as if she would never cease.
Following this, Dummling requested her hand in marriage.

However, the king was not pleased with the prospect of Dummling as a son-in-law and made various excuses, stipulating that Dummling must first produce a man capable of drinking an entire cellarful of wine.

Dummling thought of the little grey man, believing he could assist him. He went into the forest and, at the same spot where he had felled the tree, he saw a man sitting with a very sorrowful expression.

Dummling inquired what was causing him such distress, and the man replied that he suffered from an immense thirst that he couldn't quench, explaining that cold water was unbearable and that he had just emptied a barrel of wine, which felt like a mere drop on a hot stone to him.
Dummling declared he could help and invited the man to accompany him to be satisfied.

Soon afterwards he came to a city, where a king ruled who had a daughter who was so serious that no one could make her laugh. So he had put forth a decree that whosoever should be able to make her laugh should marry her. When Dummling heard this, he went with his goose and all her train before the king’s daughter, and as soon as she saw the seven people running on and on, one behind the other, she began to laugh quite loudly, and as if she would never stop. Thereupon Dummling asked to have her for his wife; but the king did not like the son-in-law, and made all manner of excuses and said he must first produce a man who could drink a cellarful of wine. Dummling thought of the little grey man, who could certainly help him; so he went into the forest, and in the same place where he had felled the tree, he saw a man sitting, who had a very sorrowful face. Dummling asked him what he was taking to heart so sorely, and he answered: ‘I have such a great thirst and cannot quench it; cold water I cannot stand, a barrel of wine I have just emptied, but that to me is like a drop on a hot stone!’
‘There, I can help you,’ said Dummling, ‘just come with me and you shall be satisfied.’
